Introduction to Programming builds on Computational Programming Solving, concentrating on computer programming in an object-oriented paradigm. By the end of this course students will be able to effectively analyse a well-defined problem, design a program solution, and will be able to efficiently implement the solution in Java. Topics include algorithms, classes and objects, object-oriented design, control structures, applets, data structures, searching and sorting, and recursion.

contentlets.description: Introduction to Programming builds on Computational Programming Solving, concentrating on computer programming in an object-oriented paradigm. By the end of this course students will be able to effectively analyse a well-defined problem, design a program solution, and will be able to efficiently implement the solution in Java. Topics include algorithms, classes and objects, object-oriented design, control structures, applets, data structures, searching and sorting, and recursion.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT1110","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT1110 - Computer Games","description":"

Computer Games takes an IT professional and computational view of the technology and industry of computer games. The focus is primarily upon the technological dimension - simulation, graphics, human computer interaction, AI, etc. - with lesser emphasis on the social and business dimensions. Further, the course contains a significant design & development theme - the generic and game specific principles of design will be examined; while students will critically analyse (from a design perspective) a successful game and develop their own game content. Finally, the course will expose students to the critical role that play has for healthy human development and the way that modern defence forces (and other organisations), including the ADF are employing serious games and utilising the technology of computer games to meet some of their training, education, recruitment, decision-support or other requirements.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5d35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96194b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Elective Tasks: Technological, Social, and Business Dimensions of Computer Games","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are exposed to a range of elective assessment tasks that cover the gamut of topics (lectures) that comprise modern computer games - the technology (e.g., simulation, graphics, networking), social (e.g., violence debate, addiction), and business (e.g., freemium, micro-transactions).

Students pick and choose the assessment tasks they wish to take, according to certain constraints, to build an eportfolio of exploration of topics.

Each assessment piece belongs to one of three categories based on the 'difficulty' and depth of work expected. These are known as Delves (1 point), Quests (2 points), and Odysseys (3 points) to evoke a sense of exploration and to draw parallels with the well known roleplaying genre of games (where players undertake adventures and become more powerful by completing those adventures - they "earn experience").

A complete list of the elective tasks can be found on the Moodle site. In essence there are some 30+; with students taking from as few as three through to a dozen or more such tasks (their choice).

 

 Elective tasks may be attempted at any time throughout session. Marking occurs fortnightly (see Feedback process for details).

To compliment the freeform nature of the elective tasks and ensure a minimum of core topics covered there are a series of fortnightly exercises for students to complete. These are relatively small and not onnerous. Details can be found on the Moodl;e site.. Students are not forced to complete these exercises but earn two points per fortnightly exercise completed..

 

Each fortnight student portfolios are examined and any completed tasks (as indicated by the student) are assessed. Assessment of tasks focusses first upon whether it is acceptable or not. If acceptable the tasks is green-lighted and the student receives the equivalent number of points. If the task is not of sufficient quality it is amber-lighted: The student is provided explicit information on what aspect(s) are the current shortcomings and told it will be reassessed on future rounds (future fortnights) of marking.

 

Each tasks - whether successful or in need of resubmission - receives individual written feedback about what the student has written in their portfolio - often with suggestions of how to improve future submissions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1535993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5135993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d535993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0135993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Serious Military Game Scenario","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"32","description":"

 

 

You are to design and develop a significant scenario in VBS3.

Students formi into teams of 2-4 ( typically 3, maximum of 4) to undertake this task. This allows a polished project to be created while potentially utilising the individual strengths of the team members to best effect (e.g., a good programmer combined with a good scenario creator). Details on the team formation will be communicated shortly.

It should be understood that this is the single most significant assessment component of the course and that a product of some quality and polish is expected.

Marks Breakdown

Each student (or student team) will submit a mission and accompanying documentation. The breakdown of marks is as follows:

  • Mission – 70%
  • Playtesting - 5%
  • Documentation – 25%

Scenario (70%)

Scenarios are marked on the basis of the gameplay experience they create and upon the sophistication, richness and integration of technologies & game elements to support that experience. In other words it is marked on the quality of the mission from a player’s point of view, and from the work, and effort that went into creating it.

As a bare minimum, a scenario should possess:

  • A definite start and end
    • A briefing for the start and an appropriate finish
    • A role and challenge for the player
    • Balance

Better quality scenarios will:

  • Be well integrated with the environment they occur in
  • Possess replayability
    • Potentially play out differently each time
    • Employ map markers and triggers in meaningful ways
    • Have an engaging back-story or be tactically sound (follow doctrine)

Scenarios judged to be of high quality will likely possess or utilise one or more of the following:

  • Novelty
    • Be different from the run-of-the-mill
    • Scripting
      • Should support the scenario created
      • Advanced Editor Features
        • Numerous options here
        • Great story, or challenge or tactical accuracy
        • Expanded options for the player
        • Appropriate usage of multimedia
          • E.g., Audio, video, images in briefing, etc.

Playtesting (5%)

Alpha versions of scenarios are to be made available (via Moodle - details available later) by Week 10. If a team makes their scenario available (by week 10) and provides meaningful feedback on at least 2-other projects also available; they will automatically earn 5%.

Meaningful feedback is good playtester feedback about the experience. What the experience was like, what worked, and what failed; questions for the designers and developers to ponder; and even suggestions. Usually this requires several play-throughs, some introspecttion, and then a short-ish report of half-a-page plus. The mechanism by which feedback is provided will be decided shortly - but is likely to be a discussion board or similar.

Documentation (25%)

As well as their mission, students are to submit a document about the design and creation process itself.  This should be maintained from the beginning of the project. The document is intended to convey the process the student undertook, record activity, and convey lessons learnt. In particular it should possess:

  • Activity Log – Every time you do some work on the scenario just add a line recording the amount of time and what you did (if a team project then also which member). For instance: Fri 13/8 – 1.5 hours – Scouted for appropriate location for mission.
  • Process Taken – An outline of how you went about designing and implementing the mission. This doesn’t have to be long but should convey the approach you followed (try to link to the lectures on design, game design, and game development if possible).
  • Design Principles Employed – Any principles you used in guiding your design and development. For instance you might have used KISS. You should state how/why/where you used each principle.
  • Lessons Learnt – What did you take away from the process? What did you learn “for next time”?
  • Key Features – Remind the marker of the key features you employed. Did you use scripting? Did you use cameras and/or music? Is it a tactically realistic mission? Etc.

 

Student teams receive comprehensive feedback for their scenario that addresses multiple individual aspects within mission design and implementation (e.g., play balance, realism, immersion, novelty, use of technology, training outcome) as well as the documentation (thoroughness, insights, lessons learned) that is produced.

 

This is one of two capstone assessment pieces so a focus of feedback concerns design and how choices in design create the experience of the user. This "completes the circle" the students began with their critical analysis of a successful game (i.e., looking at another's design) through the concept stage (writing their concept document) to the design and realisation of that design (the VBS3 scenario).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1535993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5135993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d535993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Game Design Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"18","description":"

You are to play and then analyse a successful game from a design perspective. That is you will examine key elements of the game's design and how they contribute to the play experience (gameplay) you personally experience. This is not a game review such as you would find in a game magazine or at such sites as IGN or GameSpot.

The game in question is the extremely successful title Portal from Valve. Portal was released in 2007 and subsequently won a number of "Game of the Year", "Puzzle Game of the Year", and "Best Character" awards. It has a meta/aggregate review rating score of about 90% - very high.

It is important that you play Portal yourself and perform your analysis on the basis of your play experience. Portal is available on all lab machines (under Steam). Should students wish to own their own copy they can purchase it via Steam for the PC or Mac. It is not vital that a student play all the way through Portal, though it is highly desirable (and recommended) in order to experience the full story and character development. At a minimum a student should play up to the beginning of Test Chamber 14.

Now, for your answer, write a report which analyses the design as follows:

  1. Gameplay Experience - Write 2+ paragraphs detailing what your play experience was with the game. Very briefly summarise the game itself but spend most of your discussion on the type of play you experienced. What you did and didn't enjoy, how engaging (or otherwise) you found the game etc. (At a minimum also) Make particular reference to the concepts of Flow and Interest Curvesas found in the Game Play lecture.
  2. Key Game Elements- Consider each of the following key game elements and write at least a paragraph about each - thinking as a designer:
    1. Challenge & Conflict - What level of challenge did you experience and how was the challenge balanced? What conflict existed in the game and how was it communicated?
    2. Interaction, Actions & Control - How did you interact with the game and the game world? What could you and couldn't you do in the game world?
    3. Narrative & Story - What was the game's narrative and story? What is the narrative structure?
    4. Rules - What were the implicit and explicit rules of the game and the game world that dictated how the game played?
    5. Space - How did the game define the physical space in which action occured?
    6. Skill & Chance - What skills does a player need to possess? What role does chance play?

Contribution of Game Elements to Game Experience - Now consider the 6 key elements identified above and consider how they contributed to (individually and combined) your play experience. Write at least 3 solid paragraphs about this (i.e., this is important!).


Students receive individual written feedback. The feedback addresses each of the three aspects they were asked to address: Gameplay Experience; Key Game Elements; and Contribution of Game Elements to Game Experience. Responses are individualised based on what the student has written. Indications are provided, where appropriate, of failures to meet expectations or lack of linkage to material provided via lectures. Typically, each student receives about 3 paragraphs worth of feedback.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,computer games,serious games,game design
contentlets.description: Computer Games takes an IT professional and computational view of the technology and industry of computer games. The focus is primarily upon the technological dimension - simulation, graphics, human computer interaction, AI, etc. - with lesser emphasis on the social and business dimensions. Further, the course contains a significant design & development theme - the generic and game specific principles of design will be examined; while students will critically analyse (from a design perspective) a successful game and develop their own game content. Finally, the course will expose students to the critical role that play has for healthy human development and the way that modern defence forces (and other organisations), including the ADF are employing serious games and utilising the technology of computer games to meet some of their training, education, recruitment, decision-support or other requirements.
contentlets.title: Computer Games

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BCCS (CDF) program. Students undertaking this course will attend lectures and complete the assessment tasks for ZEIT1101 Computational Problem Solving. This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BCCS (CDF) programs. Students enrolled in this course will undertake the Engineers Without Borders Challenge: a design project chosen by the students to produce an engineering solution to a problem in a developing country. To help them successfully implement their project, introductory lectures on project management, research techniques, information management, cultural and social context, and report writing will be provided. This project will provide students with an experience in solving a real-world engineering problem.

Resistance and Ohm's Law; Kirchoff's voltage and current laws; power; simple DC circuits; superposition; Thevenin's theorem; Norton's theorem; node and mesh analysis; dependent sources; electrical measurements; RMS voltages and currents; capacitance and inductance; impedance and admittance; phasors; simple AC circuits, transformers. Introduction to intrinsic and doped semiconductors; formation and characteristics of a PN junction diode; Zener and avalanche breakdown. Diode rectifier and simple filter circuits. Regulated power supplies using Zener diodes; Introduction to electronic CAD tools (SPICE); Choosing electronic components.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"35aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961960","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Test 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The class test 1 will be held in week 5 to examine the students' understanding of the contents covered in the lectures and tutorials by week 5. The test will be closed book.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b9aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pre-Labs / Post-Labs","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

For each weekly laboratory exercise, students need to complete the Pre-Lab and Post-Lab. Both Pre-Lab and Post-Lab must be submitted through the Moodle, and will be graded as S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). Full satisfactory Pre-Labs and Post-Labs earn 10% of the course marks. Unsatisfactory or no submissions will reduce the marks on a pro rata basis. The Pre-Lab is mostly on-line quiz type assignments where the solutions are provided to students immediately after the completion. The Pre-Lab preparation is essential for students to complete the lab exercises in the time available. After each lab session, students write up one-page summary report of their results and discussions as Post-Lab reports. The written feedback to the reports will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"35aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"71aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b9aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Lab report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to submit a Final Lab Report for Lab 4 DC power supply. The report is required to be submitted electronically via the DEC1 course's Moodle site. The report will have a strict page limit and formatting requirements, encouraging students to be precise and concise. The report must include reflections on the lab topic activities and the outcomes achieved, and how these activities link to what students have learnt from the lectures, tutorials and other lab activities.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"35aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"71aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b9aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Test 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":"

The class test 2 will be held in week 10 to examine the students' understanding of the contents covered in the lectures and tutorials by week 10. The test will be closed book.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b9aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f5aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1aed173db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Exam is held during the exam period, which covers all topics in the course. The exam will be closed book.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,design electronic circuits
contentlets.description: Resistance and Ohm's Law; Kirchoff's voltage and current laws; power; simple DC circuits; superposition; Thevenin's theorem; Norton's theorem; node and mesh analysis; dependent sources; electrical measurements; RMS voltages and currents; capacitance and inductance; impedance and admittance; phasors; simple AC circuits, transformers. Introduction to intrinsic and doped semiconductors; formation and characteristics of a PN junction diode; Zener and avalanche breakdown. Diode rectifier and simple filter circuits. Regulated power supplies using Zener diodes; Introduction to electronic CAD tools (SPICE); Choosing electronic components.
contentlets.title: Design of Electronic Circuits 1

This course introduces a good balance of theory, practice and laboratory investigation. It explores Ohms Law, Kirchoff's Laws, DC analysis of circuits; ideal operational amplifiers; the differences between analogue and digital signals; number systems and conversions; Binary arithmetic; Complement notation for negative numbers; Error detection and error correction codes; AND, OR and NOT operations; Formulation of Boolean expressions; Boolean theorems; Minimisation of Boolean expressions; Karnaugh maps for up to 6 variables; Analysis of sequential circuits; Stable and unstable states; Introduction to flip flops; algorithmic state machine approach to the description of digital circuits, analysis of synchronous sequential circuits, design of synchronous sequential circuits. It introduces the microcontroller as a circuit element.


The course also provides an introduction to the electrical engineering profession, the role of the electrical engineer in society and in the services; the relationship of electrical engineering to the sciences; engineering ethics; equal employment opportunity and related issues of equity; confidentiality and privacy; occupational health and safety; industrial democracy electrical engineering in society and in the services; the relationship of electrical engineering to the sciences; engineering ethics; equal employment opportunity and related issues of equity; confidentiality and privacy; occupational health and safety; industrial democracy.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,electrical engineering
contentlets.description:
This course introduces a good balance of theory, practice and laboratory investigation. It explores Ohms Law, Kirchoff's Laws, DC analysis of circuits; ideal operational amplifiers; the differences between analogue and digital signals; number systems and conversions; Binary arithmetic; Complement notation for negative numbers; Error detection and error correction codes; AND, OR and NOT operations; Formulation of Boolean expressions; Boolean theorems; Minimisation of Boolean expressions; Karnaugh maps for up to 6 variables; Analysis of sequential circuits; Stable and unstable states; Introduction to flip flops; algorithmic state machine approach to the description of digital circuits, analysis of synchronous sequential circuits, design of synchronous sequential circuits. It introduces the microcontroller as a circuit element.

The course also provides an introduction to the electrical engineering profession, the role of the electrical engineer in society and in the services; the relationship of electrical engineering to the sciences; engineering ethics; equal employment opportunity and related issues of equity; confidentiality and privacy; occupational health and safety; industrial democracy electrical engineering in society and in the services; the relationship of electrical engineering to the sciences; engineering ethics; equal employment opportunity and related issues of equity; confidentiality and privacy; occupational health and safety; industrial democracy.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,electrical engineering
contentlets.description: This course is available to students in the BE (ElecCDF) program. Students will be required to undertake a comprehensive literature review chosen from a list of topics selected or approved by the Head of School.  At least one staff member will be nominated as a supervisor to provide guidance and general supervision during the literature review and preparation of the written report and seminar. Late in the Session each student will be required to lead a seminar attended by other students and members of staff.  Evidence of sufficient progress may be required from time to time.  The literature review, which will have a nominal length of 2000 words, is to be presented not later than the first day of the examination period.  Literature reviews must be presented both typed and in electronic form. In addition, students will attend lectures and undertake assessment relating to the material outlined for ZEIT1206.
contentlets.title: Electrical Engineering Research 1B

This is a foundational course that equips students with the basic concepts of current engineering practice. It is a pre-requisite for the subsequent engineering design courses. It has three elements; a lecture series, computer aided design (CAD) practicals using CATIA and workshop practicals using the lathe. In the lecture series, student are introduced to the following; systems engineering approach to complex engineering problems, the main manufacturing processes and the fundamentals of fastenings, cutting tools and mechanical assemblies (fits, limits and tolerances).

This is a six Unit of Credit core first year course in the Bachelors of Engineering in Civil, Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering, and Bachelor of Technology in Aeronautical Engineering.  The aim of the course is to introduce students to the fundamental concepts and principles of mechanics applied by engineers. This includes both statics and dynamics.  The course also aims to foster rigorous problem solving and critical thinking skills. Engineering mechanics builds on the classical mechanics taught in Physics 1a, ZPEM1501, and applies the mathematical techniques taught in Engineering Mathematics 1a and 1b, ZPEM1303 and ZPEM1304. This course forms the basis for other core engineering courses such as Thermofluids, Mechanics of Solids and Structural Analysis

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT1504","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT1504 - Introduction to Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering","description":"

This is a foundational course designed to equip students with an introduction to concepts of engineering practice. The material addressed during this course will provide the foundations of later engineering courses. Significant aspects of the course address social context, sustainability, ethics, safety, research methods, technical report writing, graphical communication using sketching and drawing and an introduction to engineering materials (metals, polymers, ceramics and composites). This course also provides an introduction to the profession through the eyes of practicing engineers who will deliver “guest lectures” based on their career experience.


The workshop practice component of the course will provide engineering students with basic hand tool competencies and other familiarity that will be called upon in future courses. This course will be followed in Semester 2 by ZEIT1501 which will address CAD 3D modelling and drawing production (using CATIA), provide an introduction to manufacturing and develop machine tool competency (principally on a lathe). These two courses then provide the foundation for the sequence of subsequent design courses beginning with ZEIT2501 which engages students in the National “Warman Design and Build Competition”.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d44ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961987","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Technical writing - Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment will comprise a short report on a technical topic(s) discussed in the class.

Formative feedback will be given informally during the lectures/tutorials. Summative assessments will be managed through Moodle, including personalized comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"504ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"373ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Materials Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

In this assessment, students will be tasked with a design problem for which they need to come up with and justify their choice of materials for the design. Some knowledge of how materials are manufactured will also be blended in this assignment. 

Formative feedback will be given informally during the lectures/tutorials.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c4ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f3ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam will cover an assessment of all topics covered in the course. In addition, the students must complete and pass satisfactorily the Engineering workshops (including hand-tools) held during the May orange activity period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4c4ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"504ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c4ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d84ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f3ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Graphics studios (x4)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

This will be conducted as a series of assignments held in the tutorial sessions. They will focus on different drawing styles and the ability to communicate effectively through hand drawings and graphics.

Formative feedback will be given informally during the lectures/tutorials. Summative assessments will be managed through Moodle, including personalized comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"504ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"844ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Materials Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

This a open notes summative class test where the students can apply their knowledge to solve engineering problems involving materials' knowledge. 

Formative feedback will be given informally during the lectures/tutorials following the test. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9c4ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"844ed133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961965","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT1504.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

The material addressed during this course will provide the foundations of later engineering courses. Significant aspects of the course address social context, sustainability, ethics, safety, research methods, technical report writing, graphical communication using sketching and drawing and an introduction to engineering materials (metals, polymers, ceramics and composites). This course will be followed in Semester 2 by ZEIT1501 which will address CAD 3D modelling and drawing production (using CATIA), provide an introduction to manufacturing and develop machine tool competency (principally on a lathe). These two courses then provide the foundation for the sequence of subsequent design courses beginning with ZEIT2501 which engages students in the National “Warman Design and Build Competition”.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT1600","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT1600 - Introduction to Civil Engineering","description":"

This course introduces students to the Civil Engineering discipline and its various specialised fields. They will learn to effectively communicate engineering information using engineering drawings. Students will achieve knowledge of the interface between design, surveying and construction. Students will also learn surveying techniques and will be introduced to the various stages of design and construction of a residential house.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT1800","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT1800 - Introduction to Aviation Technology","description":"

This course will introduce students to the world of aviation, encompassing both civil and military operations. The course will answer the question: "What makes an aircraft fly?", in terms of aerodynamics, aircraft performance, aircraft systems and human factors. Our journey will expose students to the many issues that influence a safe flight, such as, the design and construction of modern aircraft, propulsion systems, airports, air traffic management, training, management and human performance issues. The course will also cover remotely piloted aircraft, simulators and the aviation system of the future.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c987e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961904","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

There will be one in-class test worth 15%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7487a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Historical Aviation Video (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"15","description":"

The first student group research work is where students in groups research and portray in a 10-15 minute video a War Memorial Annex historical aircraft’s purpose, crew, area of operation and a famous flight.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7487a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd87e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3c87a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Capstone Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Each students will research impact of future technoloigies on an aspect of aviation and present that in a substantial essay. The Capstone is the major assessment worth 30 per cent, but it has an essay and a class presentation split out here to clearly show diverse assessment types.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7487a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd87e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Capstone Present","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Each students will research impact of future technoloigies on an aspect of aviation and based on their essay present that to the class in a short individual presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7487a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd87e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Students maintain a portfolio during the subject where they write on at least five occasions (500-750 words) on why they are interested in aviation and how the parts of the subject enrich or changes their interest. The portfolio is also practice research and writing for students' first major essay and individual presentation in aviation (and possibly at university).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7487a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd87e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Flight Planning Laboratory (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

There is a two-hour laboratory, where students in groups plan and then implement a flight in the School simulator between two contrasting destinations and in an aircraft of choice from the X-plane stable. The laboratory report and a presentation back to the class on what they did and found are group assessments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3887a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7487a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cd87e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e087a13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT1800.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs. Students undertaking this course will attend lectures and complete the assessment tasks for ZEIT1600 Introduction to Civil Engineering for BE(Civil) students and ZEIT1504 Introduction to Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering for the other degree programs. In addition, students will attend a number of research seminars within the School and demonstrate an understanding of the research problems and solutions presented in the seminars, as an introduction to the discipline of engineering research.

contentlets.description: This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs. Students undertaking this course will attend lectures and complete the assessment tasks for ZEIT1600 Introduction to Civil Engineering for BE(Civil) students and ZEIT1504 Introduction to Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering for the other degree programs. In addition, students will attend a number of research seminars within the School and demonstrate an understanding of the research problems and solutions presented in the seminars, as an introduction to the discipline of engineering research.

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs.


Students enrolled in this course will undertake group work projects under the guidance of a research supervisor. These projects will be based upon current research activities within the department. Assessment will be in the form of a presentation of their group work and a written research paper. In addition to the project, students will receive specialist lectures and assignments in research-related topics such as measurement techniques, mathematical techniques, uncertainty analysis and presentation of data.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"68c21627db399850eb6b147a3a96197a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Gantt Chart","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The Gantt chart will be a test of the student’s understanding of the engineering problem involved with the project, and of their ability to synthesise information from a variety of sources to characterise the problems and form a plan of attack. The Gantt chart will concentrate on the individual student’s contribution to achieving the project’s aims. The Gantt chart will be produced in Microsoft Project or an open-source equivalent.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"58c21627db399850eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5cc21627db399850eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"00c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961959","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The seminar presentation will be of 10 minutes duration plus 5 minutes question time and will outline the student’s contribution to the group project, including the methodology they followed to solve their portion of the research problem, and how they used available resources to achieve the outcomes. The assessment will be a weighted average of lecturer and peer assessment of the seminar.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"10c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"58c21627db399850eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"48c21627db399850eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"70","description":"

The project report is submitted as a group, and 30% of the mark will be shared by all members of the team. Team members will designate which parts of the project they will work on, and that part of the mark for the report will be allotted to the student. This report is the same as that required by the Engineers Without Borders Challenge, and the marking scheme will be the same as that of the competition. As a general indication, each CLO will be given roughly equal weighting in the assessment of the capstone project. If the report is of a sufficiently high standard, it will be submitted to the challenge organisers. Details of the requirements for this report can be found at http://www.ewb.org.au/ewbchallenge/resources. Students are responsible for the submission of the project to EWB. It is not part of the course requirements to submit the project to the competition.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"10c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"58c21627db399850eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5cc21627db399850eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"94c21627db399850eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"80c21627db399850eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT1902.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2102","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2102 - Computer Technology","description":"

The course presents the fundamental aspects of computing, which include historic views on analogue and biological computing, and then focuses on the most important technologies for digital and neuromorphic computing. For digital computing the discussions cover binary logic and arithmetic, hardware and instruction set architectures and the fundamental concepts that underlie operating systems. For neuromorphic computing the course investigates the fundamental concepts related to 2nd and 3rd generation artificial neural networks, and presents several neuromorphic applications enabled by the digital computing technologies presented earlier in the course

The lab work is an individual task performed each week using tools relevant to each topic. These tools include Java, Matlab, INTEL assembler, and ARM assembler. Each lab session wil require a lab report.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,computer technology
contentlets.description: The course presents the fundamental aspects of computing, which include historic views on analogue and biological computing, and then focuses on the most important technologies for digital and neuromorphic computing. For digital computing the discussions cover binary logic and arithmetic, hardware and instruction set architectures and the fundamental concepts that underlie operating systems. For neuromorphic computing the course investigates the fundamental concepts related to 2nd and 3rd generation artificial neural networks, and presents several neuromorphic applications enabled by the digital computing technologies presented earlier in the course
contentlets.title: Computer Technology

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2103","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2103 - Data Structures and Representation","description":"

Data Structures and Representation is an intermediate course in computer programming, that aims to further explore computer program control and data structures, using Java as the teaching language. The main focus is on the appropriate selection and application of data structures to specific problems. Structures explored include lists, hash tables, trees, heaps, and graphs. We also explore the use of persistent data structures in text and XML files, and in SQL databases. And we further develop fundamental notions of object-oriented program design, and of software engineering ideas and techniques.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2104","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2104 - Computers and Security","description":"

A large part of this course deals with various details of cyber offensive and defensive principles, following the cyber kill chain methodology. In the context of these principles, students will learn about the legal and ethical aspects of being a cyber professional in the industry or the military, risk assessment and incident response strategies that can be taken, developments in cryptography, and the intricacies of wireless network security. Drawing on a threat–vulnerability–countermeasure paradigm combined with real-world examples demonstrated in a closed lab environment, students will gain an understanding of the link between security theory and technical computer and network security. Students will learn to comprehend formal and technical principles underlying security testing and assurance as they implement and test security.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8235993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The written assignment (essay) is a 2,500-word report on a pre-defined topic related to this course. The report should be aimed at a technical reader but one who is not an expert in the area. It should show the student’s in-depth understanding of one or more discussed in the course, and provide evidence of self-directed learning. Marking considerations include correct knowledge showing an understanding of course topics, ability to linking this work into other related areas of knowledge covered within the course, exhibition of evidence of self-directed research, clarity and structure of argumentation, careful use of references conforming to a known style, and the technical nature of the work. The essay is to be submitted via Moodle/Turnitin.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4a35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8a35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3935993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

There will be 7 labs taken during the course. Lab manuals will be provided in hardcopy and online on Moodle. The lab manuals contain questions which students need to answer in individual lab reports, to be submitted via Moodle within 5 working days after the lab dates. The lab reports are assessed on correctness of the answers and additional showing of understanding.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0e35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8a35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7135993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96197e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

The written exam is a comprehensive test on knowledge and understanding of the course material. It consists of short-answer, medium-answer, and long-answer open questions. It covers the lectures (slides and notes), the additional compulsory readings, as well as what has been learned from the labs. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0e35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4a35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8635993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8a35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b935993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961982","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Legal and Ethical Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

Early in the course, students have to take an online quiz on Moodle, testing their knowledge on legal and ethical aspects of conducting cyber operations. Students must pass the test before they are allowed to conduct labs on the Cyber Range.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8635993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f135993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961987","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT2104.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2105","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2105 - Systems Analysis and Design","description":"

This course provides a broad exposure to the IT Management, Information System Design, and Principles. The course teaches students how to use standard artefacts and methodologies to analyse and guide software development and systems projects.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f35d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment is an in-class test focussing on students’ comprehension of different software development approaches and project management related artifacts.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7e35d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ba35d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e35993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class assessment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Given a set of artifacts students will need to answer a series of questions on the given design. Additionally, students will need to produce an ER diagram.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3635d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f635d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e35d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

 

This assessment requires the students to produce a portfolio of artifacts to describe a given system and satisfy given requirements.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f635d93bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a635993bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment requires students to work in groups to develop a Software Design Document (SDD), which uses fundamental principles, development methodologies, and analysis and design practices.  The students will capture stakeholder needs and transform them into a suitable set of development requirements before mapping them into a functional design using UML.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2106","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2106 - Digital Forensics","description":"

This course will introduce students to Digital Forensics as part of the evidence and intelligence gathering process. The course will provide students with knowledge and understanding to enable the recovery of admissible evidence from computer and network systems. It will teach the skills and competencies necessary to understand how such evidence can be used for presentation in a Court of Law or for Intelligence purposes. The course will also develop knowledge and understanding of advanced forensic computing techniques and to acquire the skills to apply these successfully.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a64fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Laboratories and Practicals","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are eight lab assignemnts developed to assess the students' underdstanding for the technical work of digital forensics. For the laboratories and practicals, students have to submit the practical answers of each lab to the Moodle. The submission of each lab is due on 13 days after the lab by midnight.  The assignments are marked within a week after submission, then students receive individal feedback, marks, and model answers. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2a4fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"624fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ae4fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"da4fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ea4fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"064fddb3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Project and Written Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

20% Project & Written assignment of the course’s evaluation divided as follows: 

  • 13% team evaluation: Written report, Presentation and Quality of the project’s output.
  • 7% individual evaluation: Each student in the team will present part of the project.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2190","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2190 - Computing and Cyber Security Research 2","description":"

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BCCS (CDF) program. Students undertake problem-based learning or a research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 2 level.


As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"397209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96196e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students present a seminar on their individual research project at the end of semester (15 mins seminars, 5 mins questions). They receive a grade worth 15%, and written feedback. Half-way through the semester they have given a practice seminar of around 10 mins duration, on which they receive written feedback. 

\n

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e17209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ed7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students maintain a journal of their project work throughout the semester. The journal may be maintained in any format the student desires, and must be submitted at the end of the semester. They receive a grade worth 10%, based on the clarity, consistency, and utility of their journal entries. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"217209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2d7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a17209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ed7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"557209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961913","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"75","description":"

A 3000 to 5000 word final report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by the last day of semester. The format of the report will be a research paper, with a template provided to the students. The report will include: Abstract, Aim, Background, Method, Results, Discussion and Conclusion. The report will be graded independently by their supervisor and the course coordinator, who will then ultimately determine an appropriate grade. The students will receive written feedback on their project and their corresponding report.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"217209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2d7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a17209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e17209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ed7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9d7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT2190.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2207","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2207 - Design of Electronic Circuits 2","description":"

ZEIT2207 focusses on transistors: you will study the analysis, design, and construction of transistor-based circuits. In this 6 unit of credit course you will learn about transistor biasing, operating point selection and analysis techniques to predict circuit performance. You will compare experimental results with those gained from both simulation and theory, and learn about the limitations of each approach. This requires development of the DC and AC circuit analysis techniques learnt in ZEIT1206, DEC1. The analysis and design techniques and skills developed in this course will be used extensively in ZEIT3216, DEC3.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2208","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2208 - Programmable Digital Systems","description":"

Topics covered in this course include: introduction to the C programming language for embedded processor development, practical timing constraints when implementing digital logic circuits, registers and counters, operation of standard TTL and CMOS devices, interfacing digital circuits from different logic families, digital-to-analogue conversion, analogue-to-digital conversion, digital memory architectures, microcontrollers, programmable logic devices, introduction to field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), Introduction to the VHDL hardware description language, introduction to digital communications, computer buses and serial communications interfaces, introduction to computer networking.

This 6 unit of credit course will focus on the understanding of principles of electrical engineering. This course will enable students to design and implement an electrical engineering project using a broad range of electrical engineering fundamentals and tools including analog/digital conversion, spectrum of a signal, sampling theorem, amplitude modulation, microcontroller programming, feedback control systems, DC motors and servo motors.


The course aims are to develop sound design principles through participation in a small-group, project-based learning activity. This project is electrical in nature and students will be exposed to the broad principles of electrical design and engineering report writing. The lectures will deliver relevant material for the successful completion of the project.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2f2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Semester long project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The laboratory sessions will be dedicated to a semester-long group project. Students will be expected to apply the theory from the course notes to deliver a system which meets a set of specified requirements. This group project may require students to use course material earlier than it is covered in the tutorial. Therefore students are expected to undertake self-directed learning.

This will be a continuous assessment item, with specific deliberables to include demonstrations of system performance and formal reports, assessed at both individual and group levels.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"572e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a32e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"072e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Weekly Moodle quizzes will be delivered for each tutorial, to ensure that students are keeping up with learning material. This assessment will be largely formative.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam will test the student's understanding of the theoretical concepts presented in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1b2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"db2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"832e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961982","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2500","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2500 - Thermofluids","description":"

For centuries, engineers have been tasked with finding economical and efficient solutions to create power, transfer heat and energy and build structures immersed in fluids such as aeroplanes, dams and bridges. Future engineers will also be required to apply their knowledge to these areas, designing and analysing the next generation of such devices as well as developing new and innovative solutions to unknown problems.


The analysis and design of such equipment and technologies requires a solid foundational knowledge of the disciplines of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics. This course examines the role that thermofluids, or the disciplines of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics has on engineering. 


It develops an understanding of the basic properties of fluids before extending to simple analyses of fluids at rest and in motion. It also introduces and applies the laws of thermodynamics to well defined applications including closed and open systems and simple thermodynamic cycles.

contentlets.description:
For centuries, engineers have been tasked with finding economical and efficient solutions to create power, transfer heat and energy and build structures immersed in fluids such as aeroplanes, dams and bridges. Future engineers will also be required to apply their knowledge to these areas, designing and analysing the next generation of such devices as well as developing new and innovative solutions to unknown problems.

The analysis and design of such equipment and technologies requires a solid foundational knowledge of the disciplines of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics. This course examines the role that thermofluids, or the disciplines of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics has on engineering. 

It develops an understanding of the basic properties of fluids before extending to simple analyses of fluids at rest and in motion. It also introduces and applies the laws of thermodynamics to well defined applications including closed and open systems and simple thermodynamic cycles.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2501 - Mechanical and Electronic Design","description":"

This course aims to develop sound design practice through participation in the Warman Design and Build Project and Competition, which is a small-group, semester-long, authentic project-based learning activity. The project is unique each year but mechatronic in nature, and students will be exposed to the broad principles of mechanical and electronic design in a professional context including requirements analysis, concept development, detailed design, fabrication, testing and evaluation, teamwork and reporting. The lectures, design studio and workshop sessions will deliver the relevant material and scaffolding for the successful completion of the project.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,mechanical and electronic design,warman design and build
contentlets.description: This course aims to develop sound design practice through participation in the Warman Design and Build Project and Competition, which is a small-group, semester-long, authentic project-based learning activity. The project is unique each year but mechatronic in nature, and students will be exposed to the broad principles of mechanical and electronic design in a professional context including requirements analysis, concept development, detailed design, fabrication, testing and evaluation, teamwork and reporting. The lectures, design studio and workshop sessions will deliver the relevant material and scaffolding for the successful completion of the project.
contentlets.title: Mechanical and Electronic Design
