","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2502","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2502 - Fundamentals of Flight","description":"

This course introduces the fundamentals of aerodynamics, aircraft performance and stability. Students will be introduced to basic aeronautical concepts such as parts of the aircraft, properties of the atmosphere, altimetry and airspeed, lift and drag. Starting from the equations of continuity, momentum and energy, fluid flow equations for subsonic and supersonic flow will be derived and applied to aviation problems. Basic aerodynamic topics such as boundary layers, laminar and turbulent flow will be explained. Dynamic similitude and modelling of aircraft will be developed including flow in subsonic and supersonic wind tunnels. This course will explore aircraft performance in various equilibrium flight conditions such as level flight, climbing, turning and gliding. The concepts of aircraft stability will be introduced including derivation of the contribution of various aircraft components to overall stability.

This course covers fundamental aspects of fluid mechanics. It develops an understanding of the physical mechanisms underlying fluid flow. It contains a review of the fundamental equations of Fluid Mechanics, an expansion of the methods of momentum analysis known from Thermofluids, and a detailed discussion of the powerful technique of Dimensional Analysis, which allows the systematic discovery of parameter sets that govern the characteristic features of a flow. These techniques are used in engineering applications, such as the fluid mechanical treatment of turbomachines and devices for flow measurement. Special emphasis is given to friction effects in fluid flows. Several examples of flows in which friction is important are discussed, such as Couette flows, pipe flows and boundary layers. The final chapter of the course is an introduction to compressible flows.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2504","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2504 - Mechanics of Solids","description":"

The mechanical behaviour and analysis of solid objects under various loadings is considered in this course. The fundamental concepts of stress and strain are introduced to quantify the behaviour of structural components. The aim of the course is to provide students with fundamental knowledge regarding the examination of the stresses and strains inside bodies of finite dimensions that deform under loads using the physical properties of the materials as well as various theoretical models and concepts. Experimental material characterization and techniques for solving for stresses, strains and displacements of rods and torsional shafts, bending in beams and buckling of columns also form part of the syllabus. This 6 Units of Credit course extends the work done in Statics to enable detailed behaviour of deformable solids under complex loading to be presented.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f52eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

There will be four laboratory experiments to complete in this semester. The experiments will be performed during two laboratory periods of 3 hours duration each. A separate laboratory schedule will be distributed early in semester. The reports are to be submitted at the end of the laboratory session. After performing the experiments and taking the data, all students will then complete their reports.  The writing up will be inside the laboratory area and within the allocated three hours. No extension or postponement of report submission will be allowed. The reports must be submitted even if incomplete. Reports will be treated as quizzes and must be completed individually and independently even if the data was common between members of a group. Obviously, pre-reading of the experiment and relevant material is important.  The raw reports are issued to the students in the first week of semester.  Students must bring the reports with them together with any extra sheets of paper and graph paper that they may need when reporting the experiments. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"252eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"612eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bd2eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f92eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"152eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Test x 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The assessment of student performance during the semester is based on the results of two tests (valued at 20%+20% = 40% of the total final mark) and laboratory reports (valued at 10% of the total final mark). The tests are designed in the way that enables the lecturer to assess the student performance and at the same time to make the student think of the material presented in the test paper in the close context to the main course goals (LO 2, 3 & 4). The test results are discussed at the tutorial sessions. Solutions, answers, and typical errors made by the students are analysed and discussed to provide and stimulate true understanding of the course materials, and develop a skill for the practical knowledge implementation. To pass the test a student should demonstrate the ability to make creative use of his/her knowledge of the course in the solution process.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"612eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bd2eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f92eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d2eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam 3 hours","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

The principle of progressive assessment is implemented in order to support the learning process and provide the feedback to the students regarding their performance during the course of study. Final assessment is accomplished at the examination session (valued at 50 % of the total final mark) (LO1, 2, 3 & 4). The examination paper format and layout are designed to enable students to be well prepared to the course requirements. The examination paper format is similar to that used in the test papers.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2601","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2601 - Soil Mechanics and Engineering Geology","description":"

This is an introductory course that addresses: introductory aspects of engineering geology; engineering classification of soils and rocks;  compaction behavior of soil, stresses in soils under self weight and simple loading conditions; 1 D and 2D seepage and their effects on effective stress, and behavior of soils under1 D consolidation. Students are required to perform soil compaction, falling head and constant head permeability tests, and 1D consolidation tests using relevant Australian Standards. A demonstration is also given to show the effect of liquefaction on structure stability.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fd821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961933","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

A case will be given to the students to analyse the settlement of a site due to 1 D loading conditions. Written feedback will be given to the students within two weeks of submission.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"79821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b5821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bd821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d82d573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field trip and lab report","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

There are three laboratory tests and a field trip in the course. Students are required to write two group reports on the lab tests, and 1 individual report on the field trip.  Written feedback will be given to the students within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"79821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b5821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bd821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f1821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6582d573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

A in class quiz will be conducted before the semester break on knowledge learned during the first half of the semester. Written feedback will be given to the students within two weeks of the quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"79821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bd821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ad821973dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2602","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2602 - Hydraulic Engineering","description":"

This course covers fundamental aspects of fluid mechanics and hydraulics. It contains a review of the fundamental equations of fluid mechanics, an expansion of the methods of momentum analysis known from thermofluids, and a detailed discussion of the powerful technique of dimensional analysis, which allows the systematic discovery of parameter sets that govern the characteristic features of a flow. Special emphasis will be given to friction effects in fluid flows.


The course then examines several important applications in civil engineering, including friction and minor losses in single pipelines and pipe networks, pump-pipe systems and open channel flow; the latter will include friction losses and conservation of energy and momentum principles.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"56fd19ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961905","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Laboratories are intended to provide a practical view on fundamental problems in fluid mechanics. The students will be given the opportunity to perform assisted hands-on work that aims to reinforce the lecture material.  The two laboratories (pipe flow and open-channel flow) will each be approximately 2 hours long and will be run with groups of four students per session. Each group will be expected to prepare a detailed report on each experiment, following the standard scientific reporting structure made available in the course materials. The submitted reports will be reviewed and detailed feedback will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"56fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"92fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d6fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"39fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Three quizzes will cover course material. For the examination, the greater portion of marks will be awarded for demonstrating an understanding of the problem and its method of solution, intelligent attempts to obtain the solution and for the correct solution. Arithmetic and similar errors attract only minor penalties. Feedback will be provided through detailed discussion of the question in class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"56fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"92fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d6fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dafdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"42fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

The short project is aimed at introducing students to read and investigate further into topics in hydraulic engineering in situations that would be experienced by a practising civil engineer. A suitable list of textbooks available in the library is provided in the recommended reading section. Students work in pairs to write a report and feedback is through comments on the marked report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"56fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"92fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d6fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dafdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"50","description":"

A 3-hour final exam, which will cover material from the entire course. Feedback will be given through the release of final marks.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"56fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"92fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9afdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d6fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dafdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c2fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignments will cover relevant knowledge of fundamental fluid mechanics and applications. They are intended to foster discussion with the lecturer and amongst fellow students on the nature of the assignment problems and their solution. The detailed working of the solution and the preparation of the assignment submission itself must be your own individual work.

Assignment reports must be prepared in a clearly structured and sufficiently annotated way, clearly showing the development of the final results. Assignments reports that do not meet the basic standards for such take-home assessment tasks will not be accepted. Specific guidelines for them will be distributed in class.

Feedback will be provided through detailed comments on the marked assignments.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,hydraulic engineering
contentlets.description:
This course covers fundamental aspects of fluid mechanics and hydraulics. It contains a review of the fundamental equations of fluid mechanics, an expansion of the methods of momentum analysis known from thermofluids, and a detailed discussion of the powerful technique of dimensional analysis, which allows the systematic discovery of parameter sets that govern the characteristic features of a flow. Special emphasis will be given to friction effects in fluid flows.

The course then examines several important applications in civil engineering, including friction and minor losses in single pipelines and pipe networks, pump-pipe systems and open channel flow; the latter will include friction losses and conservation of energy and momentum principles.
contentlets.title: Hydraulic Engineering

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2603","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2603 - Civil Engineering Materials","description":"

This course aims to provide a comprehensive introduction to civil engineering materials. It covers basic topics on modern construction materials, their properties and their applications in civil engineering projects. Emphases will be given to factors that affecting material selections in terms of strength, serviceability, durability and sustainability in practice.


Course Learning Outcomes


Upon successful completion of the course, students will have acquired:


·       Understanding the basic properties of materials and ability to relate such properties to civil engineering.


·       Understanding the properties of naturally occurring materials with which civil engineers must deal.


·       Understanding properties of artificial materials and their relationship and impact on civil engineering.


·       Understanding relationships between materials properties and design needs.


·       Recognising the importance of knowledge of material properties in influencing decision making in infrastructural design that carry environmental, economical and sociological consequences.


Course content:


History and development of materials; interactions between processes, design, and properties; basic material properties; manipulating material properties; natural materials in civil engineering; soils, rocks, timbers, bamboo, natural fibres, and metals; materials in the built environment: clay, timber, steel and concrete as building materials; Materials for roads and airports construction, materials to suit design and design to suit materials; durability of civil engineering materials; relevant properties of clay bricks, timber, steel and concrete; new materials for civil engineering; civil engineering materials and the environment.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2700","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2700 - Mechanics of Machines","description":"

This course combines concepts learned in Statics and Dynamics in the context of mechanisms analysis and design. The students learn about the different types of links and joints that make up mechanisms. In the kinematics (how things move) part of the course, mechanisms are analysed using loop equations. In the kinetics (how forces interact) part of the course, the static and dynamic forces are analysed using the superposition method. Special cases of balancing of rotating masses and the design of cams are also covered.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2802","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2802 - Aircraft Systems for Aviators","description":"

This course explores the purpose and general arrangement of aircraft systems and propulsive technologies. The role of the operator - pilot or engineer - will be discussed with reference to the concept of integrated aircraft system design and function for manned and unmanned aircraft. Systems covered include engines, propellers, fuel, electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic, environmental control, navigation, undercarriage, and braking.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f587e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961998","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Safety Occurrence due Aircraft System (Group Present)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The Capstone project involves researching a formally reported aircraft safety occurrence from the last 12 months and describing the aircraft systems involved and how they contributed to the occurrence both directly and indirectly. Students present a group written report and a significant presentation to the class with questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3987e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7187e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bd87e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f987e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1987e13bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are asked to recall and describe the function of key components in the many aircraft systems covered. Students do a short essay in the examination on an aviation accident that was due to an aircraft system failure. The accident is studied and debated in class and the essay question derives from an aspect debated.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,aviation safety
contentlets.description: Using a systems approach this course will deal with the various elements which influence safety in aviation including aircrew, aircraft, maintenance, management operations and airspace with an emphasis on human performance. The focus of the course is aviation human factors - the study of the relationship between the safety and efficiency of an aviation system and the people, tasks, environment and technology making up that system, incorporating human behaviour, information processing, time management and situational awareness, judgment and decision making, the senses, human error, automation, risk management, safety culture and emergency planning. A number of aircraft incidents and accidents will be analysed to illustrate key concepts in flight safety. Industry practitioners will deliver guest lectures and local field trips to aviation safety related civil and military organizations are planned.
contentlets.title: Aviation Safety

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT2901","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT2901 - Engineering Research 2A","description":"

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Elec)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs. Students undertake problem-based learning or research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 2 level.


As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961912","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"","description":"

Present a short (up to 10 minute) introductory seminar on your project topic.

Seminar 1 will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst Seminar 2 will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"da241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"06241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Present a second more comprehensive (15 minute) seminar on 4 June 2018 to an audience of students and academics. Each CDF student will have 15 min for presentation, followed by ~5 minutes of Q&A time.

These seminars are intended to give you practice in preparing and presenting your work, and to stimulate discussion between yourself and your peers/staff in an informal and collegial atmosphere. These seminars will be assessed, and you will be given a grade and written feedback on your performance.

Seminar 1 will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst the Seminar 2 will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"da241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4e241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"75","description":"

Additionally, this course will have the following reporting requirements:

• An informal progress report is to be submitted to the CDF coordinator by your supervisor, on your behalf, on or before May 4, 2018. The report should indicate your supervisor’s assessment of your progress and his/her expectations for successful completion of the project. If this report is unsatisfactory, the CDF coordinator, supervisor and student are to determine remedial action.

• A 3000 to 5000 word Final Report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by Friday 15 June 2018. The format of the report will be a research paper, and a template will be provided by the course coordinator. This Report carries the full weighting for the course. As a guide, your Report should discuss the following:

  • Abstract: A succinct summary of the aims, method, results and conclusions of the project.
  • Aim: What the problem is.
  • Background: What the solutions are.
  • Method: How you went about solving the problem.
  • Results: What the results were.
  • Discussion and conclusion: A summary of the significance of the results, and a reflection on what you have learnt.

For more detailed information on the preparation of engineering reports, please consult the book:

  • Winckel, A. & Hart, B. (2002), “Report Writing Style Guide for Engineering Students”, 4th ed., Faculty of Engineering, University of South Australia, Adelaide; see http://www.unisa.edu.au/ltu/students/study/specific/rep ort-engineering.pdf

Further information on the seminars, and guidance on writing the Project Report, can be obtained from your project supervisor or the CDF Student Coordinator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1a245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"52241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9e241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"da241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4e241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

A research journal, either electronic or on paper will be kept, outlining the work and the time required for the work performed in the project. The journal should contain a brief summary of the aim and results on each day when work was attempted for the project. The journal is to be handed in with the final report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1a245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"52241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9e241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"da241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"86241a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT2901.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Additionally, this course will have the following reporting requirements:

• An informal progress report is to be submitted to the CDF coordinator by your supervisor, on your behalf, on or before September 7. The report should indicate your supervisor’s assessment of your progress and his/her expectations for successful completion of the project. If this report is unsatisfactory, the CDF coordinator, supervisor and student are to determine remedial action.

• A 3000 to 5000 word Final Report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by October 26. The format of the report will be a research paper, and a template will be provided by the course coordinator. This Report carries the full weighting for the course. As a guide, your Report should discuss the following:

  • Abstract: A succinct summary of the aims, method, results and conclusions of the project.
  • Aim: What the problem is
  • Background: What the solutions are
  • Method: How you went about solving the problem
  • Results: What the results were
  • Discussion and conclusion: A summary of the significance of the results, and a reflection on what you have learnt.

For more detailed information on the preparation of engineering reports, please consult the book: • Winckel, A. & Hart, B. (2002), “Report Writing Style Guide for Engineering Students”, 4th ed., Faculty of Engineering, University of South Australia, Adelaide; see http://www.unisa.edu.au/ltu/students/study/specific/rep ort-engineering.pdf 

Further information on the seminars, and guidance on writing the Project Report, can be obtained from your project supervisor or the CDF Student Coordinator.

Present a short (up to 10 minute) introductory seminar on your project topic.

The first seminar will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst the final seminar will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"63c29627db399850eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9bc29627db399850eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8bc29627db399850eb6b147a3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Present a second more comprehensive (15 minute) seminar to an audience of students and academics. Each CDF student will have 15 min for presentation, followed by ~5 minutes of Q&A time.

These seminars are intended to give you practice in preparing and presenting your work, and to stimulate discussion between yourself and your peers/staff in an informal and collegial atmosphere. These seminars will be assessed, and you will be given a grade and written feedback on your performance. The first seminar will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst the final seminar will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology
contentlets.description:
This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Elec)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs. Students undertake problem-based learning or research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 2 level.

As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,cryptography
contentlets.description: This course provides details of the history, theoretical foundations, and the current state of cryptographic algorithms. Topics may include classical cipher design and analysis; modern private key block cipher design, details, modes of use and analysis; stream ciphers; an introduction to number theory; public key encryption algorithms; digital signatures and hash functions; key management, X.509 certificates and certificate authorities; quantum computing and quantum cryptography.
contentlets.title: Cryptography

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,computer languages and algorithms,prolog,data structures
contentlets.description: This course introduces students to the main programming paradigms, comparative features of computer languages, data structures and algorithms. Paradigms covered in the course may include low-level languages, traditional imperative languages, and object-oriented, functional and logic paradigms. The course emphasises: iterative, concurrent and recursive control structures; simple linear data structures and applications especially in sorting algorithms.
contentlets.title: Computer Languages and Algorithms

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,internetworking,scalable network,advanced ip addressing,route optimization
contentlets.description: This course aims to further the student's knowledge of Internetworking with TCP/IP. In particular, it examines advanced IP addressing, routing with advanced routing protocols and network security.
contentlets.title: Internetworking

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3118","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3118 - IT Project 1","description":"

This is a capstone course in the degree. The Project affords the opportunity to apply skills and knowledge from other courses in the degree and forge a contribution to the IT discipline by a software engineering project. This complex group-based project seeks to contextualise multiple components of the ICT profession, and also incorporate Cyber-Security fundamentals.


This project requires students work in teams with a key stakeholder client to identify the requirements of a project based on high-level aims, evaluate appropriate technology choices and implementation architectures, and develop a solution that meets these needs. Such needs often include the consideration of existing business processes, software, hardware, and the development of integration pathways.


Additionally, students are expected to critically analyse and evaluate their project to better understand how design and technology choices, time-management, group interaction and client communication impact outcomes.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c68f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96198c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Personal Reflections","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Personal reflections are used to determine the growth and thought processes of course participants throughout the project. An understanding of current interpersonal and technical challenges and state, and evaluated methods of improvement. Self-reflection is a key process evaluated here.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8e8f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ca8f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"318f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"IT Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The group project is developed in a team in response to client requirements.

The project itself is assessed throughout the course, and there are multiple summative and formative components assessed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"358f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"428f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8e8f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f58f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"698f497bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Personal Contribution","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Personal contribution to the project is weighted via in-class contribution, analysis of project outcomes against tasks. Additionally, peer assessment is also taken into account.

This is a capstone course in the degree. The Project affords the opportunity to apply skills and knowledge from other courses in the degree and forge a contribution to the IT discipline by a software engineering project. This complex group-based project seeks to contextualise multiple components of the ICT profession, and also incorporate Cyber-Security fundamentals.

This project requires students work in teams with a key stakeholder client to identify the requirements of a project based on high-level aims, evaluate appropriate technology choices and implementation architectures, and develop a solution that meets these needs. Such needs often include the consideration of existing business processes, software, hardware, and the development of integration pathways.

Additionally, students are expected to critically analyse and evaluate their project to better understand how design and technology choices, time-management, group interaction and client communication impact outcomes.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3119","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3119 - Web Development and Security","description":"

Developing the server-side web application infrastructure requires an understanding in the client-server mechanisms. The course teaches how web server receives and processes requests from the users. The process creates dynamic pages, where the subsequent page view depends on what the user requests. The web infrastructure use a separate database server to persist and look up information to allow rich web content. The course further points to the weaknesses in web development from the security point of view. It shows how users can attack web sites through manipulating web requests to change the behaviour of web applications. Depending on the degree of the attacks, damages to the victim web sites varies. The course allows students to assess the degree of security of web systems.

Students will learn how to assess their code and software stack for vulnerabilities additionally they will discover how those vulnerabilities are exploited, and how to mitigate those vulnerabilities.  Historical and current approaches to exploitation and defence will be explored.


Students will gain a deep understanding of software vulnerabilities through hands on experience.


Topics covered will include: input validation, data security, cryptography, hashes, random numbers, anti-tampering, fuzzing, overflow, and Return-oriented programming.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b52f59b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The final examination will assess students' understanding of the entire course including: their understanding of the purpose of cryptography and how it is used in data communications; what cipher, cryptanalysis, cryptographic algorithm, and cryptology are; what two basic methods for transforming plain text into cipher text are; their understanding of JCE, JCA, and JSSE for encryption and authentication; the use of padding mechanisms in ciphers and identifying and correcting typical errors; and the implementation and use of authentication mechanisms in Java.

contentlets.description:
Students will learn how to assess their code and software stack for vulnerabilities additionally they will discover how those vulnerabilities are exploited, and how to mitigate those vulnerabilities.  Historical and current approaches to exploitation and defence will be explored.

Students will gain a deep understanding of software vulnerabilities through hands on experience.

Topics covered will include: input validation, data security, cryptography, hashes, random numbers, anti-tampering, fuzzing, overflow, and Return-oriented programming.
contentlets.title: Programming for Security

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3121","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3121 - Securing Networks","description":"

This course will develop students understanding of the link between security theory and network security. It will help students to comprehend formal and technical principles underlying network security testing and assurance. Students will learn to implement and test security mechanisms and technical principles in a closed laboratory environment. Students will  also apply machine learning techniques using Python scripts to classify attack events and understand intrusion detection systems. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"65fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961962","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Laboratories and Practicals","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There are nine Laboratory assessmnets in the course. For the laboratories and practicals, students have to submit the practical answers of each lab to the Moodle. The submission of each lab is due on 13 days after the lab by midnight. Within a week, the students will receive the mark, individual feedback and model asnwer for the lab questions. The weight of the assignments is 40% out of the course evaluation. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dfe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"55fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"59fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"91fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ddfe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0dfe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Project & Written Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

20% Project & Written assignment of the course’s evaluation divided as follows: 

  • 13% team evaluation: Written report, presentation and quality of the project’s output.
  • 7% individual evaluation: Each student in the team will present part of the project .

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dfe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"59fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"91fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"45fe51b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961945","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Examination of all Learning Outcomes. Different types of questions such as multiple choices, lists, and discussions. The final exam is weighted by 40% of the course evaluation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3190","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3190 - Computing and Cyber Security Research 3A","description":"

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BCCS (CDF) program. Students undertake problem-based learning or a research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 3 level.


As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"227209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students present a seminar on their individual research project at the end of semester (15 mins seminars, 5 mins questions). They receive a grade worth 15%, and written feedback. Half-way through the semester they have given a practice seminar of around 10 mins duration, on which they receive written feedback. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"127209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"027209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students maintain a journal of their project work throughout the semester. The journal may be maintained in any format the student desires, and must be submitted at the end of the semester. They receive a grade worth 10%, based on the clarity, consistency, and utility of their journal entries. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"127209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"267209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"967209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d27209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"75","description":"

A 3000 to 5000 word final report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by the last day of semester. The format of the report will be a research paper, with a template provided to the students. The report will include: Abstract, Aim, Background, Method, Results, Discussion and Conclusion. The report will be graded independently by their supervisor and the course coordinator, who will then ultimately determine an appropriate grade. The students will receive written feedback on their project and their corresponding report.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"127209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"267209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a7209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"967209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d27209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"827209f7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT3190.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3191","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3191 - Computing and Cyber Security Research 3B","description":"

This course is restricted to those students undertaking the BCCS (CDF) program. Students undertake problem-based learning or a research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 3 level.


As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"577249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961957","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"75","description":"

A 3000 to 5000 word final report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by the last day of semester. The format of the report will be a research paper, with a template provided to the students. The report will include: Abstract, Aim, Background, Method, Results, Discussion and Conclusion. The report will be graded independently by their supervisor and the course coordinator, who will then ultimately determine an appropriate grade. The students will receive written feedback on their project and their corresponding report.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1f7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5b7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cb7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"037249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students present a seminar on their individual research project at the end of semester (15 mins seminars, 5 mins questions). They receive a grade worth 15%, and written feedback. Half-way through the semester they have given a practice seminar of around 10 mins duration, on which they receive written feedback. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1f7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8f7249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f67249f7db391c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students maintain a journal of their project work throughout the semester. The journal may be maintained in any format the student desires, and must be submitted at the end of the semester. They receive a grade worth 10%, based on the clarity, consistency, and utility of their journal entries.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3215","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3215 - Signals and Systems","description":"

This course introduces descriptions of basic continuous and discrete time signals. It introduces the delta-impulse signal and its properties. Continuous-time and discrete-time systems and their properties are discussed. The convolution operation and linear system impulse response are introduced. The course presents an analysis of signals using Fourier series and Fourier transform. Properties of the Fourier transforms, Fourier spectrum and power spectrum, Parseval's theorem, energy spectral density and power spectral density are presented. An application of these transforms in sampling theory is discussed. The tool of Laplace transforms and the methods of partial fraction expansions are discussed, including the concepts of transfer functions. These tools are applied in the analysis of active filters. The course also introduces computer aided analysis of analog linear systems.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,signal and systems,fourier theory,fourier analysis,parseval theorem
contentlets.description: This course introduces descriptions of basic continuous and discrete time signals. It introduces the delta-impulse signal and its properties. Continuous-time and discrete-time systems and their properties are discussed. The convolution operation and linear system impulse response are introduced. The course presents an analysis of signals using Fourier series and Fourier transform. Properties of the Fourier transforms, Fourier spectrum and power spectrum, Parseval's theorem, energy spectral density and power spectral density are presented. An application of these transforms in sampling theory is discussed. The tool of Laplace transforms and the methods of partial fraction expansions are discussed, including the concepts of transfer functions. These tools are applied in the analysis of active filters. The course also introduces computer aided analysis of analog linear systems.
contentlets.title: Signals and Systems

ZEIT3216 focusses on the frequency response and stability of analog circuits. You will study the analysis, design, and construction of transistor-based circuits, and apply techniques and concepts from Signal and Systems (ZEIT3215) and Control Engineering (ZEIT3222) to analog circuits. In this 6 unit of credit course you will learn about differential amplifiers, multistage amplifiers, the frequency response of BJT circuits, feedback, stability, and oscillators. In the laboratory component of the course, you will analyse and design multistage differential amplifiers, high frequency oscillators, and BJT circuits with feedback. You will gain experience in prototyping high frequency circuits, and in identifying and managingparasitic components. This course builds on the analysis and design skills design skills from Design of Electronic Circuits 2 (ZEIT2207). You will design complex electronic circuits, and compare experimental results with those gained from both simulation and theory. You will refine your understanding about the limitations of each approach.

The course covers the following topics. Revision of Fourier transform and Fourier series and their properties, signal transmission through a linear system, signal bandwidths, transfer functions, amplitude modulation (AM) including double sideband, single sideband, and vestigial sideband modulations, AM modulators and demodulators, angle modulation including frequency modulation (FM), phase modulation (PM), narrowband FM, wideband FM, FM modulators and demodulators, multi-signal transmission, transmitters and receivers. Furthermore, this course provides students with an introduction to digital communication systems, line coding, pulse shaping, equalization, signal space analysis, digital modulation schemes such as ASK, FSK, BPSK, M-ary PAM, QPSK, M-PSK, M-ary QAM, demodulation and detection, bit and symbol error probabilities.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3220","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3220 - Engineering Electromagnetics","description":"

The focus of this course is on developing an understanding of the electromagnetic properties of electronic circuits and electromagnetic devices from an electrical engineering perspective. This course builds upon previous courses in electromagnetics and circuit theory, focussing on the design and utilisation of electromagnetic devices in practical situations. This course will cover transmission lines, revisit Maxwell's equations, develop free-space propagation concepts, and apply those concepts to waveguides and antennas.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,digital signal processing
contentlets.description:
The course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the following topics:

Discrete-time signals, Fourier Analysis (DFTs and DTFTs), Discrete-time filters (FIR and IIR), z-transforms, Filter design (FIR and IIR), Multirate signal processing, State-space models, State observers and state feedback, Random processes, Signal estimation, Selected topic from: Signal detection, Adaptive filters, Wavelet transforms, Hidden Markov models, Deep learning
contentlets.title: Digital Signal Processing and Control

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3222","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3222 - Control Engineering","description":"

This course will focus on the analysis of linear dynamic systems and their control. The course will enable students to design effective feedback control using a broad range of control design tools including mathematical modelling of system components, block diagram manipulation, linearisation, Laplace transform, root locus, frequency domain and state space techniques. Students will study practical controllers such as the PID controller. The analysis aspect of the course is relevant to almost every other course in engineering. Automation is deeply embedded in our society and a good understanding of controls is essential for all engineers.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e2f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This is a formative assessment and the students are tested on the material in between the tests. Each test is under examination conditions of 50 minutes duration. The marked tests are returned normally in the next lecture/tutorial and students are explained as to what was expected in the form of the solution and which principles were tested.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"122f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"962f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"aa2f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d22f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"862f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab work reports, presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

There are ten laboratory exercises of two hours duration each. The laboratory exercises have a complete cycle of how controllers are designed in the real-world. Firstly we start with mathematical modelling, followed by parameter identification using experimental measurements, and finally the students design and test different control methods using frequency domain and state-space representation based tools.

Students submit two comprehensive laboratory reports. The first laboratory report summarises their work with system analysis and the second report is on system design. 

The reports are marked and promptly returned to the students and then students have an opportunity to discuss how the reports can be improved.

The laboratory exercises have a direct impact on how well the students understand the theory in the lectures meaning that the laboratory exercises and lectures are tightly coupled. At times a concept is first introduced in the laboratory and then discussed in the lectures making laboratory an integral part of learning the theory.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"122f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"262f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"622f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"962f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961946","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"aa2f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d22f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e62f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961954","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"862f99b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This is a summative assessment. The students are tested on the entire course content. It is a closed-book examination using a standard calculator (without memory) and at times an A4 sheet of paper with hand-written notes. Each component of the course is giving equal space in the examination questions.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology
contentlets.description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts of software project management.  An overview of software life cycle processes is provided.  This is followed by an examination of several key life cycle processes and activities, including: software development, risk management, software measurement, verification, validation, and quality assurance.
contentlets.title: Software Project Management

This course will develop students' skills and competencies in problem solving, developing understanding and implementation skills to choose appropriate levels of abstraction, producing competencies in the analysis, design and implementation of modelling, simulation, and evaluating solution options, and developing skills in the implementation of one or more of the following: ethical frameworks, social issues, and practical organisational and/or governmental problems. Topics will include concepts of modelling, continuous and discrete systems, random number generation and tests for randomness, time-stepped and event-stepped simulation, object oriented simulation techniques, statistical analysis of output, verification and validation approaches of simulation models.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,engineering structures
contentlets.description: This course extends the concepts of Mechanics of Solids to applications of Structural Mechanics in Aeronautical and Mechanical Engineering. The topics treated will include bending of indeterminate beams and unsymmetric beams, torsion and transverse loading of thin walled and stiffened structures, energy methods of structural analysis, failure analysis of metallic structures, introduction to fracture mechanics and fatigue behaviour.
contentlets.title: Engineering Structures

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3501 - Engineering Materials","description":"

This  course deals with the selection and use of engineering materials for aerospace and mechanical engineering applications.  It builds on the scientific and technology basis of the Year 2 prerequisite course in Engineering Materials and Chemistry (ZINT2501) and is the capstone materials course.  The course is structured so as to provide a framework for sound and balanced decision making in the selection and use of these materials.  It also provides guidance in the use of Codes and Standards in engineering practice.  The course comprises two major topics addressing issues in the selection, use and behaviour of metals, ceramics; and polymers and composites in broad engineering practice.  The emphasis is on developing an understanding of the critical inter-relationship between decisions made in the various stages of an engineering project, namely during the design phase, in the selection of materials, and in fabrication.  This course interfaces with design courses in Years 3 and 4 of the various engineering programs.

The final examination (closed book) covers the polymers and composites topics and addresses the leaning outcomes LO1, 2, & 3.

Test 1 (closed book) covers the Metals and Ceramics topics. The test addresses the learning outcomes LO1, 2, & 3. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"043e5133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"403e5133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c43e5133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7b2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments x 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The assignments are an opportunity for students to research and report on a topic of interest related to the course.  This will enhance their understanding of the course topics, broaden their engineering competencies, and develop their skills in independent research, investigation and report writing. The assignments address the learning outcomes LO1, 2, 3, & 4. The feedback is provided using the rubrics developed for each assignment.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3502","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3502 - Vibration and Control Engineering","description":"

This course provides a foundation in modelling dynamics of engineering systems and leads to solution of practical problems in vibration and automatic control. Free body diagrams and energy methods will be shown. Solution of free and forced response will be investigated. Basic vibration analysis will be used to apply vibration isolation methods. Multiple degree of freedom systems including lumped parameter systems will be introduced leading to the eigenvalue problem and modal analysis. The course will enable students to analyse and design effective feedback control using a broad range of control design tools including mathematical modelling of system components, block diagram manipulation, linearisation, Laplace transform and root locus. Students will study practical controllers such as the PID controller.


The course builds upon the knowledge from the earlier course on dynamics along with mathematics.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,vibration and control engineering
contentlets.description:
This course provides a foundation in modelling dynamics of engineering systems and leads to solution of practical problems in vibration and automatic control. Free body diagrams and energy methods will be shown. Solution of free and forced response will be investigated. Basic vibration analysis will be used to apply vibration isolation methods. Multiple degree of freedom systems including lumped parameter systems will be introduced leading to the eigenvalue problem and modal analysis. The course will enable students to analyse and design effective feedback control using a broad range of control design tools including mathematical modelling of system components, block diagram manipulation, linearisation, Laplace transform and root locus. Students will study practical controllers such as the PID controller.

The course builds upon the knowledge from the earlier course on dynamics along with mathematics.
contentlets.title: Vibration and Control Engineering

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3503","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3503 - Aerodynamics","description":"

ZEIT 3503 is a 3rd year 6UoC core course for the BE Aero and BTech Aero programs.


This course builds on ZEIT2500 Thermofluids and ZEIT2503 Fluid Mechanics. The fluid mechanical knowledge assumed in the present course is the knowledge of the physical principles and, in particular, the conservation laws governing fluid flow and the forces exerted by fluids as they flow over solid objects.


The primary aim of this course is to impart knowledge and understanding of how wings and other bodies produce aerodynamic forces known as lift and drag in flight/motion. The course also aims at elucidating the physical origins of the more subtle aspects of the interaction between a fluid and a solid.


As flight speed rises, the physical behaviour of the flow around a solid body, such as an aircraft, alters markedly causing major changes in the forces the flow exerts on the body. Detailed understanding of flow behaviour is therefore vital for ensuring that an aircraft will behave as desired throughout the full range of its flight regime.


A further aim is to have students experience the acquisition of non-intuitive knowledge that is not easily accessible. This fits into the whole program’s underlying purpose to teach students how to learn.


A third aim is to demonstrate that such apparently esoteric theory can inform us about flight in “the real world”.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6a2e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a62e1133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a2eddffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"7","weighting":"2","description":"

A one-hour laboratory towards the end of the course aims at applying the theories of compressible flows and shock waves in a wind tunnel test scenario. These tests will be run in groups of up to four students.

A lab report is to be submitted by each group. The marked and annotated lab report will be returned to the students.
