","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3504","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3504 - Aircraft and Systems Design 1","description":"

This 6UOC is the capstone sequence of the Aeronautical Engineering Program.  The course introduces the requirements and initial sizing elements of aircraft and systems design and the relevant aircraft standards and regulations.  Students are exposed to the three phases of aircraft design, but before undertaking any design work students are required to develop design requirements.  Following the development of the design specification, the student becomes involved in the conceptual design of an aircraft.  Students will observe the development of a fixed wing or rotary wing aircraft using initial sizing parameters, then estimate of maximum take-off weight, wing loading, power loading, aerodynamic coefficients and physical dimensions during the first iteration of the design. The second part of the course reviews the design of aircraft systems, including undercarriage, flight controls, fuel, hydraulic, emergency, and electrical systems, and the integration of systems these into the aircraft.   Finally, students evaluate their designs through simulated flight-testing of aircraft handling qualities.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"277fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Written Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

As part of your design project, each student will write an 8 page written report on one of the four aspects of the aircraft design process.  These reports will be scaffolded by formative feedback on a rough draft, and are designed as a way for you to document your design process but, very importantly, practice your TECHNICAL WRITING SKILLS in preparation for your thesis project

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"177fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"537fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9f7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"db7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"077fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Milestones","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Each group will be required to provide evidence of continuous action on their design project by meeting prescribed milestones in the tutorial sessions.  These milestones are assessed either satisfactory or unsatisfactory, and design teams must obtain 60% satisfactory completion to pass this assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"177fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"537fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9f7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"db7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Industry Inspired Design Reviews","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This type of assessment is that they mimics the kinds of things
you will do in your careers after University. You are never asked in the real world to
demonstrate knowledge in a short time frame without access to outside materials like
you are on a test. In the real world, you will have meetings with engineering managers
and customers, and it’s your job to convince them of the validity and applicability of
your work. In order to do this, you need to do the following things (in order)
1. Anticipate the questions and problems that you will need to address or that might
be asked about your work
2. Analyse the problems you identify rigorously, with justification for the methods
that you use and a basis to claim that they are accurate
3. Prepare supporting materials to back up your claims and persuade your manager
/ client of your solutions

You will get detailed written feedback after the design review as well as in person feedback during the review and after in tutorial sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"177fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"537fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9f7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cb7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Presentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The individual presentation is designed to do two things: to give you a chance to get feedback on your design work prior to the design review from both the teaching staff and fellow students, and to assess your oral presentation skills.  Each student will be responsible for presenting one of the four blocks of design work to the course and 50% of the mark will be based on presentation skills.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"177fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"537fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9f7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"db7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cb7fd5f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT3504.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course is looked upon as an integrating course to bring in the concepts of statics and dynamics as applied to aircraft under the influence of aerodynamic forces and moments.  The initial part of the course deals with the basics associated with vibration and control of dynamic systems including the concepts of natural frequency, damping ratio, transfer functions, specifications and their relationship to natural frequency and damping ratios.  This part also introduces the basic control systems and their analysis using the root locus technique.  The main part of the course deals with the dynamics of the aircraft under the influence of aerodynamic forces and moments. The mathematical modelling of the aircraft, its transfer functions and aerodynamic stability derivatives are discussed.  The simplified analysis using short period and phugoid motions for longitudinal dynamics is discussed.  This is used to relate the longitudinal dynamics to the spring-mass-damper system from the vibrations part .  The natural frequency and damping ratio are correlated with the design of the aircraft and the aerodynamic properties.   Stability augmentation and autopilots along with Handling Qualities of the aircraft as specifications for control design is discussed next.   The lateral dynamics, in particular to the Dutch roll motion and its damping, are discussed.  The effects of gust and practical implementation of control systems in aircraft is also  introduced.

The course explains how three critical disciplines (project management, systems engineering and capability sustainment) coexist and interrelate during the stages of a typical medium-complexity development project.


Project management (PM) is presented using the Project Management Body of Knowledge. Key project management tools such as the work breakdown structure, cost estimating and schedule development, are taught and practiced using a popular project management software application.


The key systems engineering (SE) principles and processes are presented and several systems-engineering tools such as use cases, functional-flow block diagrams and specification practice and are practiced.


The course also introduces the discipline of capability sustainment, including modern concepts such as product lifecycle management and the extended enterprise. The course introduces students to lifecycle cost analysis and the analysis of system lifecycle concepts to derive system requirements for incorporation in the system specification.

contentlets.description:
The course explains how three critical disciplines (project management, systems engineering and capability sustainment) coexist and interrelate during the stages of a typical medium-complexity development project.

Project management (PM) is presented using the Project Management Body of Knowledge. Key project management tools such as the work breakdown structure, cost estimating and schedule development, are taught and practiced using a popular project management software application.

The key systems engineering (SE) principles and processes are presented and several systems-engineering tools such as use cases, functional-flow block diagrams and specification practice and are practiced.

The course also introduces the discipline of capability sustainment, including modern concepts such as product lifecycle management and the extended enterprise. The course introduces students to lifecycle cost analysis and the analysis of system lifecycle concepts to derive system requirements for incorporation in the system specification.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3600","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3600 - Structural Analysis","description":"

In this course, students will learn the fundamentals of the behaviour of elastic structures composed of line elements, i.e. skeletal structures, when subjected to various actions. They will become familiar with commonly used structures and will be able to analyse the effects of forces on various components such as frames, trusses, beams and beam-columns. Students will learn of the significance of deflections for structures and how they may be assessed using a variety of techniques including matrix structural analysis.

contentlets.description: In this course, students will learn the fundamentals of the behaviour of elastic structures composed of line elements, i.e. skeletal structures, when subjected to various actions. They will become familiar with commonly used structures and will be able to analyse the effects of forces on various components such as frames, trusses, beams and beam-columns. Students will learn of the significance of deflections for structures and how they may be assessed using a variety of techniques including matrix structural analysis.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3601","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3601 - Environmental Engineering","description":"

This course introduces the principles and applications of environmental engineering. It includes the fundamentals of environmental chemistry (thermodynamics and kinetics), biology (including single species kinetics, interacting species and material and energy flows) and unit operations. Applications include studies of the dispersion of pollutants, surface water pollution, soil and groundwater contamination, air pollution, noise pollution, and global environmental impacts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5aed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961949","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial-style and presentation-style assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

A number of tutorial-style or presentation-style assignments will be issued during this course, which will constitute part of the formal assessment. The first category will involve tutorial-type questions and/or computations. They must be prepared in a clearly structured and sufficiently annotated way so that the development of the final results is clearly shown. The second category will consist of presentation-style assignments and/or debates. The assignments are intended to foster discussion with the lecturers, other staff and fellow students on the nature of the assignment problems and their solution. The detailed working of the solution and the preparation of the assignment submission itself must be your own work. 

The written component of the assignments should be submitted on Moodle. Please submit the main assignments in pdf format only (not doc format), in a single document, with all fonts embedded (otherwise it will be corrupted and unreadable). Please do not make multiple submissions based on each page of your assignment! You must also attach all supporting information (e.g. spreadsheet, Matlab or Maple files, etc). 

All assignment submissions must also be enclosed in the SEIT coversheet, which will be made available on Moodle.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"02ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4aed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5eed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"86ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c2ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"31ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Fieldwork/Laboratory Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

A major fieldwork and laboratory assignment will also be conducted in this course, worth 7 marks.  This will involve a field excursion for the sampling of polluted waters, which will then be analysed in the laboratory for coliform bacteria, run by the School of PEMS. The fieldwork will be conducted in accordance with the ‘UNSW Fieldwork Guideline’ and ‘Fieldwork Authorisation & Medical Questionnaire for Students (OHS009)’.

The laboratory component will run for approximately 2 hours and will be run for groups of four students. Each group will prepare a joint group report on the experiment, following the standard scientific reporting structure to be given as part of this course. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4aed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"86ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-Session Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The examination components of the assessment provide assurance that the knowledge and understanding demonstrated are your own and a measure of that knowledge and understanding. They also provide an extra incentive for study. The mid-session quiz will be 2 hours long, and make up 25% of the marks.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4aed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"86ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c2ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b1ed55ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The examination components of the assessment provide assurance that the knowledge and understanding demonstrated are your own and a measure of that knowledge and understanding. They also provide an extra incentive for study. 

The final examination will be 3 hours long, and make up 50% of the marks. It will be held either in the final week of session or the November exam period. Detailed instructions for the final exam will be issued with the examination timetable.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,environmental engineering
contentlets.description: This course introduces the principles and applications of environmental engineering. It includes the fundamentals of environmental chemistry (thermodynamics and kinetics), biology (including single species kinetics, interacting species and material and energy flows) and unit operations. Applications include studies of the dispersion of pollutants, surface water pollution, soil and groundwater contamination, air pollution, noise pollution, and global environmental impacts.
contentlets.title: Environmental Engineering

contentlets.description:
The topics to be covered in this course are:

  • Shear strength of soils
  • Principles of laboratory direct shear and triaxial testing
  • Lateral earth pressure theory and design of retaining structures
  • Stability of retaining structures
  • Slope stability
  • Ground Investigation
  • Stress analysis in geotechnical engineering
  • In-situ load transfer and settlement based on elastic theory
  • Bearing capacity theory

This course introduces the design of a range of steel and timber members and member connections using relevant Australian Standards. Students are also introduced to the determination of appropriate design loads for structures and their components - in particular normal gravity induced loads and wind loads.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1b5f91f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes and Tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

The three tests will be held during the semester in to cover the topics of (i) Loads on Structures,  (ii) Bolted and Welded Steel Connections, and (iii) Timber Engineering. In addition, for the steel design part, three quizzes will be conducted on the topics of (i) tension members, (ii) compression members and (iii) Beam design.

This course starts by introducing and discussing concepts and methods of reinforced concrete design. Students will learn how to analyse and design rectangular and flanged reinforced concrete beams. The acquired skills will be used by the students to design one-way slabs. Deflections of beams and one-way slabs will be analysed and designed for. The skills developed at this stage enable students to learn correct detailing and presentation of their design work. Students will then learn the philosophy and methods of design of two-way reinforced concrete slabs which includes designing for punching shear in flat plates and flat slabs. Students will then be introduced to the design of short and slender reinforced concrete columns and will develop the capacity to design columns for a axial and biaxial effects. This part naturally concludes with principles and methods used in designing reinforced concrete footings. Prestressed concrete will be introduced to the extent of familiarising students with its concepts through simple design examples.

This course consists of two modules. Students have to pass in both modules.


Module 1: Foundation Engineering.


Subjects for Module 1:


  • Stress-strain-strength relationships
  • Unsaturated soil mechanics and related strength
  • Shallow foundations (theories and design)
  • Deep foundations (theories and design)
  • Foundations on problematic soils.

 


Module 2: Pavement Engineering.


Subjects for Module 1:


  • Natural materials for road and airfield pavement construction
  • Investigation and field testing for pavements
  • Bituminous materials
  • Rigid and flexible roads and introduction to airfield pavements
  • Structural design of unsealed and sealed pavements
  • Pavement evaluation and maintenance
  • Introduction to pavement management.

contentlets.description:
This course consists of two modules. Students have to pass in both modules.

Module 1: Foundation Engineering.

Subjects for Module 1:

  • Stress-strain-strength relationships
  • Unsaturated soil mechanics and related strength
  • Shallow foundations (theories and design)
  • Deep foundations (theories and design)
  • Foundations on problematic soils.

 

Module 2: Pavement Engineering.

Subjects for Module 1:

  • Natural materials for road and airfield pavement construction
  • Investigation and field testing for pavements
  • Bituminous materials
  • Rigid and flexible roads and introduction to airfield pavements
  • Structural design of unsealed and sealed pavements
  • Pavement evaluation and maintenance
  • Introduction to pavement management.

This course provides an introduction to the standard practice in transport planning and traffic engineering. It will cover the basic topics of travel demand forecasting and traffic flow theory for civil engineering applications.


The course contents include four-step transport planning method, trip generation, trip distribution, mode choice, traffic assignment, traffic flow diagrams, geometric design, and horizontal and vertical alignments of highways.


Basic knowledge in statistics, surveying and engineering drawing is required.

A comprehensive design and calculation exercises to familiarise students with basic transport planning, traffic assignment and road alignment design. Students are required to submit their progress reports during the sememster and their final report at the end of the semester. Feedback will be provided within 2 weeks after submitting the reports.

Five short quizzes will be given during the semester to monitor the learning process and ensure a smooth learning experience for students. Each quiz would take nearly one hour to complete, and they all will be administered online. Feedback will be provided within 1 week after each quiz.

contentlets.description:
This course provides an introduction to the standard practice in transport planning and traffic engineering. It will cover the basic topics of travel demand forecasting and traffic flow theory for civil engineering applications.

The course contents include four-step transport planning method, trip generation, trip distribution, mode choice, traffic assignment, traffic flow diagrams, geometric design, and horizontal and vertical alignments of highways.

Basic knowledge in statistics, surveying and engineering drawing is required.

This course fits in the design stream for mechanical engineering.  It follows on from ZEIT1501 Engineering Practice and Design and ZEIT2501 Mechanical and Electronic Design. It is followed by ZEIT4700 Mechanical Design 2. It has a prerequisite of ZEIT2501 Mechanical and Electronic Design, but expects students to be familiar and appropriately competent across all aspects of the first 5 semesters of the degree plan. This 6-unit course provides further exposure to design principles, processes and methods, as used in industry, for requirement analysis, concept design, preliminary design and detail design including CAD. Students will acquire familiarity with a range of components and gain competence in sizing and selection of the components to achieve desired functionality. They will also be engaged in an integrative project.


 


This 6-unit course is divided into three parts: Design (40%), Component Design (35%) and CAD (CATIA) (25%). Lectures, Studio sessions and Labs will be used throughout the session to cover the above aspects.

contentlets.description:
This course fits in the design stream for mechanical engineering.  It follows on from ZEIT1501 Engineering Practice and Design and ZEIT2501 Mechanical and Electronic Design. It is followed by ZEIT4700 Mechanical Design 2. It has a prerequisite of ZEIT2501 Mechanical and Electronic Design, but expects students to be familiar and appropriately competent across all aspects of the first 5 semesters of the degree plan. This 6-unit course provides further exposure to design principles, processes and methods, as used in industry, for requirement analysis, concept design, preliminary design and detail design including CAD. Students will acquire familiarity with a range of components and gain competence in sizing and selection of the components to achieve desired functionality. They will also be engaged in an integrative project.

 

This 6-unit course is divided into three parts: Design (40%), Component Design (35%) and CAD (CATIA) (25%). Lectures, Studio sessions and Labs will be used throughout the session to cover the above aspects.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3701","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3701 - Heat Transfer and Refrigeration","description":"

This course develops an understanding of the heat transfer mechanisms of conduction, convection and electromagnetic radiation, as well as the thermodynamics of gas mixtures, humidification and air stream mixing. These concepts are applied to ideal and real refrigeration and air conditioning cycles. A range of engineering applications involving steady and non-steady heat conduction, forced and free convection, and emission and heat transfer between black and grey bodies are examined with the aid of analytical and numerical techniques.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"df1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Heat transfer project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

A number of heat exchanger design/heat transfer studies options will be provided and the student/team will select one to work on which is to be submitted at the end of the semester. The students are allowed time to discuss the project with the lecturer to assist them in directing the project in the appropriate direction as well as advise on how to write up the project report. A feedback is provided after the report has been marked and this will be done through the moodle site.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5b1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"971e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"071e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Heat transfer and refrigeration laboratory","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":null,"learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1f1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5b1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d31e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"471e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961993","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Heat transfer and refrigeration final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is an open book exam. The prescribed textbook and a copy of the printed lecture notes are allowed.

Students may request a meeting with the lecturer for feedback after the final course results have been posted by SAS.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1f1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5b1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"971e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d31e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Heat transfer and refrigeration worksheets and assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

These include worksheets, tutorials and self directed assignments. Worksheets in the heat transfer section are used in tutorials to reinforce and assist the student in learning to apply the lecture material. The students are expected to gain problem solving skills and the worksheets will form the basis of the material for the quizzes. The worksheets will be the primary vehicle for monitoring the student progress and correlating the student’s performance in the quizzes and final exam. The refrigeration section has a major assignment. The assignment marking will focus mainly on the procedures undertaken in answering the question rather than the final answer itself so a clear explanation and set-out of the answer is required. Solutions to the worksheets and assignments will be given after the submitted work has been marked.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1f1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5b1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d31e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b21e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Heat transfer x 2 quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Two 50-60 minute quizzes will be held during the semester following the completion of the following modules – conduction and convection. They relate to the heat transfer section. Each quiz is worth 10% of the total marks, giving a total of 20% to the quizzes. These quizzes are open book but only the textbook and printed lecture overheads may be used. The first quiz will occur prior to the census date. Answers to the quizzes will be provided with overall feedback on moodle after the quizzes have been marked.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,aviation safety
contentlets.description: The focus of this course will be on systems safety management programs. Topics will cover the role of proactive safety systems including: crew resource management, safety culture, operational reporting systems, safety audits, attitudinal and behavioural assessment and other metrics. The course will cover accident prevention strategies, risk management and safety program evaluation methodology. Case studies will be used to illustrate safety concepts.
contentlets.title: Advanced Aviation Safety

The aim of this course is to introduce students to Air Traffic Management (ATM). The course will cover fundamental concepts in ATM such as communication, navigation and surveillance as well as Air Traffic Control operations and procedures.


The course will also introduce the role of airports and impact of weather in ATM. Students will learn about the environmental impact of aviation and human factor issues in air traffic. Advanced ATM concepts and future air traffic research programs ie SESAR & NextGen will also be introduced.


The course will also cover computer simulation, quantitative modelling of Air Traffic Control (ATC) problems and may involve a field visit.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,airspace complexity cdr algorithms environment,air traffice management atm
contentlets.description:
The aim of this course is to introduce students to Air Traffic Management (ATM). The course will cover fundamental concepts in ATM such as communication, navigation and surveillance as well as Air Traffic Control operations and procedures.

The course will also introduce the role of airports and impact of weather in ATM. Students will learn about the environmental impact of aviation and human factor issues in air traffic. Advanced ATM concepts and future air traffic research programs ie SESAR & NextGen will also be introduced.

The course will also cover computer simulation, quantitative modelling of Air Traffic Control (ATC) problems and may involve a field visit.
contentlets.title: Air Traffic Management

This course will provide an introduction to airport operation and systems and will cover the topics of airport planning, airport operations, airport navigation aids, airport weather, airport procedure charts and airport quantitative modelling


Aspects of the design and operation of airport systems will also be reviewed. The course will cover interaction of various airport sub-systems and their impact on the overall performance of air transportation system through quantitative modelling. Students will also gain an insight into trade-offs amongst conflicting objectives of various stakeholders/users of airports for e.g. military, airlines, safety regulators, air navigation service providers and airport authorities. The course will also provide students an understanding of environmental impact of airports and possible strategies to manage it. Tutorials will include qualitative and quantitative analysis of problems relevant to airport operations. The course will include a field trip to an airfield.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,airport operations,airport systems,environmental impact of airports,airport weather,airport modelling
contentlets.description:
This course will provide an introduction to airport operation and systems and will cover the topics of airport planning, airport operations, airport navigation aids, airport weather, airport procedure charts and airport quantitative modelling

Aspects of the design and operation of airport systems will also be reviewed. The course will cover interaction of various airport sub-systems and their impact on the overall performance of air transportation system through quantitative modelling. Students will also gain an insight into trade-offs amongst conflicting objectives of various stakeholders/users of airports for e.g. military, airlines, safety regulators, air navigation service providers and airport authorities. The course will also provide students an understanding of environmental impact of airports and possible strategies to manage it. Tutorials will include qualitative and quantitative analysis of problems relevant to airport operations. The course will include a field trip to an airfield.
contentlets.title: Airport Operations and Systems

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3901","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3901 - Engineering Research 3A","description":"

This course is restricted to students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Elec)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs. Students undertake problem-based learning or research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 3 level.


As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"83245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961998","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"75","description":"

Additionally, this course will have the following reporting requirements:

• An informal progress report is to be submitted to the CDF coordinator by your supervisor, on your behalf, on or before May 4, 2018. The report should indicate your supervisor’s assessment of your progress and his/her expectations for successful completion of the project. If this report is unsatisfactory, the CDF coordinator, supervisor and student are to determine remedial action.

• A 3000 to 5000 word Final Report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by Friday 15 June 2018. The format of the report will be a research paper, and a template will be provided by the course coordinator. This Report carries the full weighting for the course. As a guide, your Report should discuss the following:

  • Abstract: A succinct summary of the aims, method, results and conclusions of the project.
  • Aim: What the problem is.
  • Background: What the solutions are.
  • Method: How you went about solving the problem
  • Results: What the results were.
  • Discussion and conclusion: A summary of the significance of the results, and a reflection on what you have learnt

For more detailed information on the preparation of engineering reports, please consult the book:

  • Winckel, A. & Hart, B. (2002), “Report Writing Style Guide for Engineering Students”, 4th ed., Faculty of Engineering, University of South Australia, Adelaide; see http://www.unisa.edu.au/ltu/students/study/specific/rep ort-engineering.pdf

Further information on the seminars, and guidance on writing the Project Report, can be obtained from your project supervisor or the CDF Student Coordinator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0b245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0f245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"87245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cb245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"36245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961973","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"","description":"

Present a short (up to 10 minute) introductory seminar on your project topic.

The Seminar 1 will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst the Seminar 2 will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cb245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Present a second more comprehensive (15 minute) seminar to an audience of students and academics. Each CDF student will have 15 min for presentation, followed by ~5 minutes of Q&A time.

These seminars are intended to give you practice in preparing and presenting your work, and to stimulate discussion between yourself and your peers/staff in an informal and collegial atmosphere. These seminars will be assessed, and you will be given a grade and written feedback on your performance.

The Seminar 1 will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst the Seminar 2 will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cb245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b2245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

A research journal, either electronic or on paper will be kept, outlining the work and the time required for the work performed in the project. The journal should contain a brief summary of the aim and results on each day when work was attempted for the project. The journal is to be handed in with the final report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0b245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0f245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"87245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fa245a2bdb399850eb6b147a3a96196e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT3901.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT3902","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT3902 - Engineering Research 3B","description":"

This course is restricted to students undertaking the BE(Aero)(CDF), BE(Civil)(CDF), BE(Elec)(CDF), BE(Mech)(CDF), or BTech(Aero)(CDF) programs. Students undertake problem-based learning or research project on a nominated topic approved by the course authority in a specific discipline area that is commensurate with study at Year 3 level.


As one of the aims of the program is to further develop critical thinking and independent research skills, the project will involve "hands on" research experience in collaboration with a staff member and their research team. A supervisor, who will work closely with the student, will manage each project. Final assessment will be based on a written paper and an oral presentation, with appropriate weighting.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"28e29a27db399850eb6b147a3a96193a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

A research journal, either electronic or on paper will be kept, outlining the work and the time required for the work performed in the project. The journal should contain a brief summary of the aim and results on each day when work was attempted for the project. The journal is to be handed in with the final report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2ce29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ace29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e8e29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ece29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ce25a27db399850eb6b147a3a9619eb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"75","description":"

Additionally, this course will have the following reporting requirements:

• An informal progress report is to be submitted to the CDF coordinator by your supervisor, on your behalf, on or before September 7. The report should indicate your supervisor’s assessment of your progress and his/her expectations for successful completion of the project. If this report is unsatisfactory, the CDF coordinator, supervisor and student are to determine remedial action.

• A 3000 to 5000 word Final Report is to be submitted by email, and in bound form, by October 26. The format of the report will be a research paper, and a template will be provided by the course coordinator. This Report carries the full weighting for the course. As a guide, your Report should discuss the following:

  • Abstract: A succinct summary of the aims, method, results and conclusions of the project.
  • Aim: What the problem is.
  • Background: What the solutions are.
  • Method: How you went about solving the problem
  • Results: What the results were
  • Discussion and conclusion: A summary of the significance of the results, and a reflection on what you have learnt.

For more detailed information on the preparation of engineering reports, please consult the book:

  • Winckel, A. & Hart, B. (2002), “Report Writing Style Guide for Engineering Students”, 4th ed., Faculty of Engineering, University of South Australia, Adelaide; see http://www.unisa.edu.au/ltu/students/study/specific/rep ort-engineering.pdf

Further information on the seminars, and guidance on writing the Project Report, can be obtained from your project supervisor or the CDF Student Coordinator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2ce29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"60e29a27db399850eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ace29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e8e29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ece29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54e25a27db399850eb6b147a3a9619f0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"","description":"

Present a short (up to 10 minute) introductory seminar on your project topic.

Seminar 1 will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst the Seminar 2 will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"60e29a27db399850eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ece29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"98e25a27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Present a second more comprehensive (15 minute) seminar to an audience of students and academics. Each CDF student will have 15 min for presentation, followed by ~5 minutes of Q&A time.

These seminars are intended to give you practice in preparing and presenting your work, and to stimulate discussion between yourself and your peers/staff in an informal and collegial atmosphere. These seminars will be assessed, and you will be given a grade and written feedback on your performance.

Seminar 1 will not contribute to the final course mark, whilst Seminar 2 will carry a mark weighting of 15%. Note that, although these seminars don’t contribute substantially to the final course mark, they are a compulsory part of the course assessment, and a failing grade will be recorded for the course if they are not satisfactorily presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"60e29a27db399850eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ece29a27db399850eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d0e25a27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e7","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT3902.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,computational fluid dyamics,fluent cfx flowizard
contentlets.description: This course provides a hands-on introduction to Computational Fluid Dynamics using Matlab and a variety of commercial CFD codes such as Fluent, CFX, or Flowizard. Treatment of different flow regimes such as incompressible/compressible, steady/unsteady, laminar/turbulent is examined. Numerical techniques such as panel methods, finite difference and finite volume methods are developed. Numerical error, stability, convergence, and automatic and manual grid generation strategies are examined in the application of CFD to engineering problems.
contentlets.title: Computational Fluid Dynamics

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4004 - Geosynthetics and Ground Improvement","description":"

This course presents the design and implementation of a range of ground improvement technologies including the use of geosynthetics. Details are as: soft soil engineering; PVD and surcharging; soil reinforcement; geosynthetics; drainage and filtration design using geosynthetics; reinforced soil wall; reinforced soil slope; reinforced embankment on soft clay; and case histories.

This course provides an introduction to the principles of naval architecture and ship design. Students will be exposed to a range of vessels and their behaviours. Key topics include ship stability, ship structures and the ship performance. The course will be delivered through a combination of lectures and tutorials.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,naval architecture,ship design,hull modelling
contentlets.description: This course provides an introduction to the principles of naval architecture and ship design. Students will be exposed to a range of vessels and their behaviours. Key topics include ship stability, ship structures and the ship performance. The course will be delivered through a combination of lectures and tutorials.
contentlets.title: Naval Architecture

This is an Engineering elective course, specially designed for students wishing to specialise in the Aircraft or Ground/Marine Vehicle Maintenance. The aim of this course is to introduce you to the basic principles, theory and applications of the major non-destructive inspection (NDI) techniques employed in the manufacturing and maintenance environments in industry, and the application of the information gained from NDI, i.e. size and location of flaws, to structural integrity assessment.
The first part of the course will provide an exposure to various traditional NDI techniques including liquid penetrant, ultrasonics, magnetic particle, radiography and eddy current testing, as well as an introduction to new and emerging health monitoring techniques. The second part of the course will focus on damage tolerance, durability assessment and fatigue life estimation, using failure criteria, fracture mechanics, stress life and fatigue crack growth theories.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,structural integrity,linear elastic fracture mechanics,crack growth analysis and fatigue life estimation
contentlets.description:
This is an Engineering elective course, specially designed for students wishing to specialise in the Aircraft or Ground/Marine Vehicle Maintenance. The aim of this course is to introduce you to the basic principles, theory and applications of the major non-destructive inspection (NDI) techniques employed in the manufacturing and maintenance environments in industry, and the application of the information gained from NDI, i.e. size and location of flaws, to structural integrity assessment.
The first part of the course will provide an exposure to various traditional NDI techniques including liquid penetrant, ultrasonics, magnetic particle, radiography and eddy current testing, as well as an introduction to new and emerging health monitoring techniques. The second part of the course will focus on damage tolerance, durability assessment and fatigue life estimation, using failure criteria, fracture mechanics, stress life and fatigue crack growth theories.
contentlets.title: Structural Integrity Assessment

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,rotorcraft engineering,rotor head designs
contentlets.description: Students will be exposed to a number of topics in rotorcraft engineering. Basic helicopter configurations, such as co-axial, tandem and autogiro, are compared. Course starts with actuator disc theory and moves to more sophisticated blade element techniques for both vertical and forward flight. Special cases include autorotation an flight in ground effect. Students are introduced to the use of dimensional analysis to reduce rotorcraft flight test data and standardise test results.Design considerations such as ground resonance, crash worthiness and fatigue safe life will also be discussed. Linearised models of helicopter dynamics are developed proceeding to useful conclusions regarding helicopter stability and flight control.
contentlets.title: Rotorcraft Engineering

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4008","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4008 - Integrated Mechanical Design","description":"

This is a capstone design course for the engineering program where students undertake a design project, as a team, under simulated business conditions, using the systems engineering approach. The design team is tutored through the engineering development processes including:


  • The overarching project management.
  • Requirements engineering and specification practice.
  • Technical performance measures.
  • Design and optimisation of system elements.
  • Interface control and system integration.
  • Failure mode and effect analysis.
  • Lifecycle design considerations such as availability and serviceability.
  • Product cost analysis.
  • Manufacturability analysis.
  • Technical risk management and design reviews.

Individual students will design at least one element of the system.


Experts from within the school and externally are consulted as required. Internal and external experts are also involved in the design reviews which are the main means of assessment for the course.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,mechanical design
contentlets.description:
This is a capstone design course for the engineering program where students undertake a design project, as a team, under simulated business conditions, using the systems engineering approach. The design team is tutored through the engineering development processes including:

  • The overarching project management.
  • Requirements engineering and specification practice.
  • Technical performance measures.
  • Design and optimisation of system elements.
  • Interface control and system integration.
  • Failure mode and effect analysis.
  • Lifecycle design considerations such as availability and serviceability.
  • Product cost analysis.
  • Manufacturability analysis.
  • Technical risk management and design reviews.

Individual students will design at least one element of the system.

Experts from within the school and externally are consulted as required. Internal and external experts are also involved in the design reviews which are the main means of assessment for the course.
contentlets.title: Integrated Mechanical Design

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4013","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4013 - Hypersonics and Advanced Propulsion","description":"

ZEIT4013 is a 6 Unit of Credit elective course that investigates in detail the fluid dynamic phenomena that occur at hypersonic speeds, concentrating on problems in the areas of atmospheric entry and supersonic combustion propulsion.  The course aims to provide students with practical skills in analytically and computationally predicting important behaviours of hypersonic flows.


The course follows on from the third-year aerodynamics course ZEIT3503, but no prior knowledge of compressible flow is assumed.  It is important for students to remember the Navier-Stokes equations from second and third year fluids courses, as these are fundamental to explaining the behaviour of hypersonic flows.


The course assumes that the students have a preliminary knowledge of fluid mechanical principles, acquired in the two second-year core fluids courses for aeronautical and mechanical engineers, ZEIT2500 and ZEIT2503. Some computer programming experience in the MATLAB environment is highly recommended, as the assignment work in this course is heavily based around MATLAB.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0c2e9dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961930","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students must achieve a mark of more than 40% in the final exam to pass the course.  It is an open-book examination designed to cover the entire material of the course.  Feedback is provided only in terms of the final course mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0c2e9dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"482e9dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"802e9dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"882e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c42e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3f1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are asked to provide a written literature review on one specific area of current hypersonics research, based upon a survey of recent papers.  Feedback is presented in the form of comments on their written reports.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"482e9dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"631e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Viscous and Inviscid Flow Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This is a written assignment containing a variety of hand-calculations and computational simulations pertaining to the inviscid and viscous flow topics of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"882e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c42e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cc2e9dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb1e5dffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Computational (DSMC) Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment tests the students' ability to construct a simulation of a simple flow using the Direct Simulation Monte Carlo method, either through use of a commercial package for a real-world problem or by computing a simpler problem from first principles in Matlab.  Assessment is based upon the structure, modularity, readability and quality of documentation of the code, and the quality of interpretation of the code's results.  Feedback is provided by comments on the returned assignment report.

ZEIT4013 is a 6 Unit of Credit elective course that investigates in detail the fluid dynamic phenomena that occur at hypersonic speeds, concentrating on problems in the areas of atmospheric entry and supersonic combustion propulsion.  The course aims to provide students with practical skills in analytically and computationally predicting important behaviours of hypersonic flows.

The course follows on from the third-year aerodynamics course ZEIT3503, but no prior knowledge of compressible flow is assumed.  It is important for students to remember the Navier-Stokes equations from second and third year fluids courses, as these are fundamental to explaining the behaviour of hypersonic flows.

The course assumes that the students have a preliminary knowledge of fluid mechanical principles, acquired in the two second-year core fluids courses for aeronautical and mechanical engineers, ZEIT2500 and ZEIT2503. Some computer programming experience in the MATLAB environment is highly recommended, as the assignment work in this course is heavily based around MATLAB.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4014","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4014 - Impact Dynamics","description":"

This course explores the science of impact. It will provide the student with a thorough understanding of the mechanisms behind collisions. This will include the study of how materials deform dynamically during impacts and how the deformation is affected by geometry, material properties and the size of the impact. This course will also explore ballistic penetration and the analytical and computational approaches that can be used to predict what happens to a material or structure during ballistic penetration. An overview of protection methodologies will be discussed including (and not limited to): ceramic armour; explosive reactive armour; concrete bunker approaches and protecting fortified structures and vehicles.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,explosives,detonation,defence,warhead,ballistics,armour
contentlets.description: This course explores the science of impact. It will provide the student with a thorough understanding of the mechanisms behind collisions. This will include the study of how materials deform dynamically during impacts and how the deformation is affected by geometry, material properties and the size of the impact. This course will also explore ballistic penetration and the analytical and computational approaches that can be used to predict what happens to a material or structure during ballistic penetration. An overview of protection methodologies will be discussed including (and not limited to): ceramic armour; explosive reactive armour; concrete bunker approaches and protecting fortified structures and vehicles.
contentlets.title: Impact Dynamics

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4015 - Advanced Design of Steel Structure","description":"

This course is aimed to both broaden and deepen students professional knowledge on structural steel design. Students will be exposed to broaden topics related to use of cold form steel, high strength steel and nonlinear analysis procedure. They will also be taught on advance topics in structural steel design including plastic design and design of plate girder.


Course Learning Outcomes


Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:


·       Understand the basic of plastic theory and calculate plastic resistance of steel section


·       Apply plastic analysis to obtain the collapse mechanism and failure mode of steel frame


·       Appreciate the important of nonlinear analysis for steel structures


·       Understand the basic actions and responses of plate girder


·       Design simple plate girder with transverse stiffeners


·       Understand the basic differences between different kinds of steel including normal strength steel, cold-formed steels and high strength steel


·       Master the basic principle of AS4600 for cold-formed steel design


·       Appreciate the impacts of welding and evaluated temperature on steel structures


Course content:


Revision of basic materials; Concept of plastic analysis and plastic hinge; Section properties for plastic analysis; Plastic hinge shape factor and conditions of collapse ;Theorems of plastic analysis; Plastic analysis of frame and ICR; Plastic analysis examples; Nonlinear analysis for steel structures; Introduction to plate girder; Behaviours and actions of plate girder; Resistance to bending and shear; Design for stiffener and end post; Design examples; Cold-formed steels and Introduction to AS 4600; Welding and temperature effects; High strength and alternative steels

All students will be asked to complete an individual plate girder design exercise. Materials and data for the design will be given a few weeks before the semester break and they must submit their designs within one week after the break. All the designs will be reviewed and compared. Feedback on students' performances will be given before the last teaching week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3ebbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4bbbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"66bbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Simple design exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be given two simple design exercises to complete during two tutorial classes (one before and one after the break). Feedback will be given to students in the following class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"03bbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76bbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"87bbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b2bbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"c3bbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aebbb0b7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961975","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4154 - Deep Learning","description":"

This course exposes engineering, computer science, and cyber security students to the different aspects of Deep Learning including Optimisation Formulation and Algorithms for Training and Regularisation, Deep Feedforward Networks, Convolution Networks, Recurrent and Recursive Networks, Deep Reinforcement Learning, AutoEncoders, Deep Generative Models, and applications in image and video processing, timeseries analysis, communication networks, robotics and control, and  human performance. The course is designed specifically to prepare 4th Yr students to do a thesis in Artificial Intelligence by giving them in-depth technical foundations in the machine learning sub-field of Deep Learning.

contentlets.description: This course exposes engineering, computer science, and cyber security students to the different aspects of Deep Learning including Optimisation Formulation and Algorithms for Training and Regularisation, Deep Feedforward Networks, Convolution Networks, Recurrent and Recursive Networks, Deep Reinforcement Learning, AutoEncoders, Deep Generative Models, and applications in image and video processing, timeseries analysis, communication networks, robotics and control, and  human performance. The course is designed specifically to prepare 4th Yr students to do a thesis in Artificial Intelligence by giving them in-depth technical foundations in the machine learning sub-field of Deep Learning.

This is a six units of credit course with six contact hours per week – three lecture hours, one tutorial hour, and two laboratory hours.


Power systems are being transformed in two significant ways.  Firstly, the devices used for the power generation are changing and secondly, the interconnection of these devices to form a smart grid is being done in many ways. This transformation is supported by the new communication and computing technologies.


This course will cover the essentials of smart grid analysis, dynamics of the renewable resources-based generators, different grid formations, and the underlying communications and computation technology.


The practical focus of this course is to study analysis and design tools to form a flexible grid for a few residential units or a remote military base.


Handbook Entry


Fundamentals of power system analysis; Fundamentals of Synchronous machines; Voltage and Angle Stability; Solar generation devices and control; Wind generation devices and control; Energy storage devices and control; Smart metering; Demand response; Big data analytics; Communications & Computing for smart grids; SCADA and Cybersecurity for smart grids; Microgrids.

contentlets.description:
This is a six units of credit course with six contact hours per week – three lecture hours, one tutorial hour, and two laboratory hours.

Power systems are being transformed in two significant ways.  Firstly, the devices used for the power generation are changing and secondly, the interconnection of these devices to form a smart grid is being done in many ways. This transformation is supported by the new communication and computing technologies.

This course will cover the essentials of smart grid analysis, dynamics of the renewable resources-based generators, different grid formations, and the underlying communications and computation technology.

The practical focus of this course is to study analysis and design tools to form a flexible grid for a few residential units or a remote military base.

Handbook Entry

Fundamentals of power system analysis; Fundamentals of Synchronous machines; Voltage and Angle Stability; Solar generation devices and control; Wind generation devices and control; Energy storage devices and control; Smart metering; Demand response; Big data analytics; Communications & Computing for smart grids; SCADA and Cybersecurity for smart grids; Microgrids.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,systems engineering process
contentlets.description: Systems Engineering provides a framework within which to develop an understanding of the processes and management practices associated with the Systems Engineering discipline. The underlying Systems Engineering process is presented and is shown to be applied repeatedly throughout the entire system lifecycle. Attention then focuses on the broad topic of Systems Engineering Management and some of the activities normally associated with engineering management are detailed. The course also introduces tools commonly used in Systems Engineering and details how Systems Engineering coexists with other disciplines (particularly Project Management, Quality Management and Integrated Logistics Support Management).
contentlets.title: Systems Engineering

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4225","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4225 - Satellite Communications","description":"

This course covers fundamentals of satellites, including applications, orbits, propagation and link calculations, system hardware for space and ground segments, multiplexing and multiple access techniques, network design and future trends. Furthermore, it provides students with fundamentals of signals and noise associated with satellite communications, as well as transmission concepts, including analogue transmission rates with respect to distortionless transmission, amplitude and delay distortions with equalisation, nonlinear distortion with companding, and carrier-to-noise ratio; and digital transmission rates with respect to line codes, intersymbol interference, pulse shaping and equalisation, bit energy-to-noise density and error probabilities.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,satellite communications,satellite orbits,satellite frequency bands
contentlets.description: This course covers fundamentals of satellites, including applications, orbits, propagation and link calculations, system hardware for space and ground segments, multiplexing and multiple access techniques, network design and future trends. Furthermore, it provides students with fundamentals of signals and noise associated with satellite communications, as well as transmission concepts, including analogue transmission rates with respect to distortionless transmission, amplitude and delay distortions with equalisation, nonlinear distortion with companding, and carrier-to-noise ratio; and digital transmission rates with respect to line codes, intersymbol interference, pulse shaping and equalisation, bit energy-to-noise density and error probabilities.
contentlets.title: Satellite Communications

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4226","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4226 - Digital Image Processing and Target Detection","description":"

The aim of this course is to introduce digital image processing techniques and their applications in target detection. Countless images are generated every day from various types of cameras, such as regular RGB cameras, LIDAR scanners, IR cameras, multi/hyperspectral scanners, depth cameras and more. The cameras can be mounted on driverless cars, UAV, aircraft or satellites. They form part of the big data to handle and to utilise for information mining and target detection. Digital image processing is a computer-based technique which carries out manipulation, enhancement, compression and representation of the information embedded.  Machine learning and artificial intelligence algorithms can then be applied for target detection, classification and identification. The topics covered in this course are the key elements in computer vision and artificial intelligence for a wide range of applications in various disciplines and fields, including robot control, search and rescue, surveillance and Earth observation. 


This course covers basic concepts and fundamental methodologies applicable to digital image processing: Image registration; image enhancement in spatial and spatial frequency domains; image coding and compression; deep learning, image segmentation and classification; applications in remote sensing, defence and security, law enforcement and space management.
