contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,digital image processing
contentlets.description:
The aim of this course is to introduce digital image processing techniques and their applications in target detection. Countless images are generated every day from various types of cameras, such as regular RGB cameras, LIDAR scanners, IR cameras, multi/hyperspectral scanners, depth cameras and more. The cameras can be mounted on driverless cars, UAV, aircraft or satellites. They form part of the big data to handle and to utilise for information mining and target detection. Digital image processing is a computer-based technique which carries out manipulation, enhancement, compression and representation of the information embedded.  Machine learning and artificial intelligence algorithms can then be applied for target detection, classification and identification. The topics covered in this course are the key elements in computer vision and artificial intelligence for a wide range of applications in various disciplines and fields, including robot control, search and rescue, surveillance and Earth observation. 

This course covers basic concepts and fundamental methodologies applicable to digital image processing: Image registration; image enhancement in spatial and spatial frequency domains; image coding and compression; deep learning, image segmentation and classification; applications in remote sensing, defence and security, law enforcement and space management.

Radar Fundamentals; Radar Application; Pulse Radar Concepts: Range-Related Calculations, Blind Range, Range Resolution, Maximum Unambiguous Range; Radar Antennas; Radar Range Equation; Pulse Integration; Radar Cross Section; Continuous Wave Radar Concepts; Frequency-Modulated Continuous Wave Radar Concepts; Pulse Doppler Radar Concepts; Moving Target Identification Radar Concepts; Tracking Radar Techniques: Target Acquisition, Sequential Lobbing, Conical Scanning, Monopulse Tracking Techniques, Scan on Receive Only, Range Tracking, Velocity Tracking; Pulse Compression Radar Concepts: Range Resolution, Blind Range, Design Issues; Synthetic Aperture Radar Concepts: Unfocussed and Focussed Synthetic Aperture Radar, Beamwidth, Angular Resolution; Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar Concepts; Radar Receiver Techniques; Imaging Radar; Range and Cross-Range Resolution; Image Formation and Characteristics; Backscatter Characteristics of Targets and Clutters.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4230","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4230 - Electrical Engineering Design Practice","description":"

In this course the knowledge and skills gained in the three Design of Electronic Circuits (DEC) courses and other specialist Electrical Engineering courses throughout the first three years of the Electrical Engineering program are applied to solve a specified electronic system design task. Students work individually and in small groups to design, construct and test various sub-systems, and then integrate these components to produce the final system solution. A strong project management philosophy underpins the engineering approach adopted in this course. The final stage of the course focuses on an evaluation of the design methodology, the completed system's performance as compared to the initial requirements, and a reflection of the overall project experience and lessons learned.

Planning review provides a chance for the group and individuals to present how they will solve different issues in the project. At this stage, a system-level approach will be assessed highlighting the good points of the approach, risks, and mistakes.  Feedback will be provided to the group on the overall organization of the project.

Planning review provides a chance for the group and individuals to present how they will solve different issues in the project. At this stage, a system-level approach will be assessed highlighting the good points of the approach, risks, and mistakes.  Feedback will be provided to the individual on his/her ideas for his/her sub-system.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"021fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"391fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f91fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"511fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress review presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

The progress review presentation aims to assess what the group has achieved at about 1/2 of the semester. It will also identify risks, problems, and delays for the project. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"021fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"391fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"751fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b11fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c21fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ce1fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f91fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a91fd5b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress review report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

The progress review report will assess the mid-semester progress of the sub-system. Feedback will be given on the amount of work achieved, creativity, quality of the technical solutions.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology
contentlets.description: In this course the knowledge and skills gained in the three Design of Electronic Circuits (DEC) courses and other specialist Electrical Engineering courses throughout the first three years of the Electrical Engineering program are applied to solve a specified electronic system design task. Students work individually and in small groups to design, construct and test various sub-systems, and then integrate these components to produce the final system solution. A strong project management philosophy underpins the engineering approach adopted in this course. The final stage of the course focuses on an evaluation of the design methodology, the completed system's performance as compared to the initial requirements, and a reflection of the overall project experience and lessons learned.
contentlets.title: Electrical Engineering Design Practice

This course is only avalilable to those students who have finished their ZEIT4500 Engineering Project A with high standard (normally at least a DN grade) as a 6 UoC expansion of the original project as a technical elective course. In general, an expansion of the scope of the original project is required.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Preliminary Report and Viva","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The student will in consultation with the supervisor/s develop an Interim Report that outlines the scope and significance of the intended research. It will define where this project sits in the wider context of its application, and will include a project management timeline. It will detail reading and progress made on the project up till the date of submission. This will serve as a document to address in the oral defence. It should be submitted by email to the supervisor and the Panel Chair.

An oral defence or Viva to a small panel of academics of your project direction, and partial work towards the objectives will be scheduled in Weeks 11 and 12 of your first project semester for ZEIT4500. The submitted Preliminary Report above, will serve as supporting documentation in this defence. The members of the Panel will assign a mark. The format of the Viva will be communicated to you and the Panel.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"576f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5f6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d76f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"db6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

A Seminar of 12 minutes duration with 3 minutes of question time will be conducted in Week 11 and 12 of your second project semester the week. The audience of this seminar will be your supervisors, peers, academic and technical staff, and members of the general public. The academic members of the audience will assess this work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"576f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5f6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d76f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"876f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Research Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

A 10 page Research Summary is a written reflection on the project definition, impact, significance, and conclusions will be submitted for review to the School Undergraduate Journal. It is a communication of your contribution to the focus area and engineering discipline. It will be submitted electronically in PDF format to the School student journal (JUER, https://ojs.unsw.adfa.edu.au/index.php/juer/index) .Guidelines on document structure are provided. Your supervisor and Panel will also provide guidance on how to write and structure this document to best communicate the significance of your project work to the area of research.

All research summary reports must go through the Turnitin check via the course Moodle site. All students must submit their draft versions two weeks before the project seminar week for a prelim screening so that they can use the Originality Report generated to improve their final version. The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 (or Week 14 for students who start their projects in Semester 1) of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5f6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"a36f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d76f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"db6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"ef6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"876f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Specific Deliverable","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

A Project Specific Deliverable will be identified by your supervisor as reasonable documentation required to support and document the project work so it may be continued by others. This may include electronic working files and designs, documentation of the operations of tools and software used in the project, a traditional research thesis, etc. The form of this deliverable will be detailed in writing at the outset of your study and the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed, and will have been recognised by the Panel as representing a similar workload as required of other students enrolled in this course. The Project Specific Deliverable should be provided directly to the supervisor by Monday, revision week of the second project semester, and the quality and content will form part of their assessment of your work.

A Seminar of 12 minutes duration with 3 minutes of question time will be conducted in Week 11 and 12 of your second project semester the week. The audience of this seminar will be your supervisors, peers, academic and technical staff, and members of the general public. The academic members of the audience will assess this work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"576f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5f6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9b6f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d76f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"876f15f3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Research Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

A 10 page Research Summary is a written reflection on the project definition, impact, significance, and conclusions will be submitted for review to the School Undergraduate Journal. It is a communication of your contribution to the focus area and engineering discipline. It will be submitted electronically in PDF format to the School student journal (JUER, https://ojs.unsw.adfa.edu.au/index.php/juer/index) .Guidelines on document structure are provided. Your supervisor and Panel will also provide guidance on how to write and structure this document to best communicate the significance of your project work to the area of research.

All research summary reports must go through the Turnitin check via the course Moodle site. All students must submit their draft versions two weeks before the project seminar week for a prelim screening so that they can use the Originality Report generated to improve their final version. The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 (or Week 14 for students who start their projects in Semester 1) of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

A Project Specific Deliverable will be identified by your supervisor as reasonable documentation required to support and document the project work so it may be continued by others. This may include electronic working files and designs, documentation of the operations of tools and software used in the project, a traditional research thesis, etc. The form of this deliverable will be detailed in writing at the outset of your study and the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed, and will have been recognised by the Panel as representing a similar workload as required of other students enrolled in this course. The Project Specific Deliverable should be provided directly to the supervisor by Monday, revision week of the second project semester, and the quality and content will form part of their assessment of your work.

contentlets.description: This course is only avalilable to those students who have finished their ZEIT4500 Engineering Project A with high standard (normally at least a DN grade) as a 6 UoC expansion of the original project as a technical elective course. In general, an expansion of the scope of the original project is required.
contentlets.title: Electrical Engineering Project Extension

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4500","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4500 - Engineering Project A","description":"

This course is the “capstone” of your degree. It consolidates findings and the skills developed and refined throughout the degree. It affords the opportunity to take these skills and knowledge from other courses in the degree and forge a valuable contribution by research to the discipline. Students can take significant ownership of a minor body of research and reflect this to the wider community by presentation and written submission. In doing so students will learn and refine skills in managing a low risk project.

The student will in consultation with the supervisor/s develop an Interim Report that outlines the scope and significance of the intended research. It will define where this project sits in the wider context of its application, and will include a project management timeline. It will detail reading and progress made on the project up till the date of submission. This will serve as a document to address in the oral defence. It should be submitted by email to the supervisor and the Panel Chair.

An oral defence or Viva to a small panel of academics of your project direction, and partial work towards the objectives will be scheduled in Weeks 11 and 12 of your first project semester for ZEIT4500. The submitted Preliminary Report above, will serve as supporting documentation in this defence. The members of the Panel will assign a mark. The format of the Viva will be communicated to you and the Panel.

All research summary reports must go through the Turnitin check via the course Moodle site. All students must submit their draft versions two weeks before the project seminar week for a prelim screening so that they can use the Originality Report generated to improve their final version. The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 (or Week 14 for students who start their projects in Semester 1) of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

A Project Specific Deliverable will be identified by your supervisor as reasonable documentation required to support and document the project work so it may be continued by others. This may include electronic working files and designs, documentation of the operations of tools and software used in the project, a traditional research thesis, etc. The form of this deliverable will be detailed in writing at the outset of your study and the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed, and will have been recognised by the Panel as representing a similar workload as required of other students enrolled in this course. The Project Specific Deliverable should be provided directly to the supervisor by Monday, revision week of the second project semester, and the quality and content will form part of their assessment of your work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2bec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"2fec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"67ec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"7bec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9fec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a3ec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ebec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"13ec1d3fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Preliminary Report and Viva","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The student will in consultation with the supervisor/s develop an Interim Report that outlines the scope and significance of the intended research. It will define where this project sits in the wider context of its application, and will include a project management timeline. It will detail reading and progress made on the project up till the date of submission. This will serve as a document to address in the oral defence. It should be submitted by email to the supervisor and the Panel Chair.

An oral defence or Viva to a small panel of academics of your project direction, and partial work towards the objectives will be scheduled in Weeks 11 and 12 of your first project semester for ZEIT4500. The submitted Preliminary Report above, will serve as supporting documentation in this defence. The members of the Panel will assign a mark. The format of the Viva will be communicated to you and the Panel.

A Seminar of 12 minutes duration with 3 minutes of question time will be conducted in Week 11 and 12 of your second project semester the week. The audience of this seminar will be your supervisors, peers, academic and technical staff, and members of the general public. The academic members of the audience will assess this work.

A 10 page Research Summary is a written reflection on the project definition, impact, significance, and conclusions will be submitted for review to the School Undergraduate Journal. It is a communication of your contribution to the focus area and engineering discipline. It will be submitted electronically in PDF format to the School student journal (JUER, https://ojs.unsw.adfa.edu.au/index.php/juer/index) .Guidelines on document structure are provided. Your supervisor and Panel will also provide guidance on how to write and structure this document to best communicate the significance of your project work to the area of research.

All research summary reports must go through the Turnitin check via the course Moodle site. All students must submit their draft versions two weeks before the project seminar week for a prelim screening so that they can use the Originality Report generated to improve their final version. The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 (or Week 14 for students who start their projects in Semester 1) of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology
contentlets.description: This course is the “capstone” of your degree. It consolidates findings and the skills developed and refined throughout the degree. It affords the opportunity to take these skills and knowledge from other courses in the degree and forge a valuable contribution by research to the discipline. Students can take significant ownership of a minor body of research and reflect this to the wider community by presentation and written submission. In doing so students will learn and refine skills in managing a low risk project.
contentlets.title: Engineering Project A

It will define where this project sits in the wider context of its application, and will include a project management timeline. It will detail reading and progress made on the project up till the date of submission. This will serve as a document to address in the oral defence. It should be submitted by email to the supervisor and the Panel Chair.

An oral defence or Viva to a small panel of academics of your project direction, and partial work towards the objectives will be scheduled in Weeks 11 and 12 of your first project semester for ZEIT4500. The format of the Viva will be communicated to you and the Panel.

A 10 page Research Summary is a written reflection on the project definition, impact, significance, and conclusions will be submitted for review to the School Undergraduate Journal. It is a communication of your contribution to the focus area and engineering discipline. It will be submitted electronically in PDF format to the School student journal (JUER, https://ojs.unsw.adfa.edu.au/index.php/juer/index) Guidelines on document structure are provided. Your supervisor and Panel will also provide guidance on how to write and structure this document to best communicate the significance of your project work to the area of research.

All research summary reports must go through the Turnitin check via the course Moodle site. All students must submit their draft versions two weeks before the project seminar week for a prelim screening so that they can use the Originality Report generated to improve their final version. The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 (or Week 14 for students who start their projects in Semester 1) of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology
contentlets.description: This course is the “capstone” of your degree. It consolidates findings and the skills developed and refined throughout the degree. It affords the opportunity to take these skills and knowledge from other courses in the degree and forge a valuable contribution by research to the discipline. Students can take significant ownership of a minor body of research and reflect this to the wider community by presentation and written submission. In doing so students will learn and refine skills in managing a low risk project.
contentlets.title: Engineering Project B

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4502","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4502 - Aircraft and Systems Design 2","description":"

Students in Aircraft and Systems Design 2 will continue the preliminary design that they began in the first semester of the class with a greater focus on detailed design and testing. The course is divided into four parts, similar to ASD1. The course first develops much more detailed estimates of the design lift, drag, and weight and balance distributions.  Second, a propulsion system design is undertaken and performance of the aircraft estimated.  Third, simulated flight testing is conducted to evaluate the aircraft’s dynamic stability characteristics. Finally, the methods of wind tunnel testing will be used to measure drag and compare with predictions.  Concurrently with these activities, students will be conducting an individual open-ended design project related to their aircraft design.


This course is a 6 UOC capstone course and relies on the entire scope of knowledge gained in the undergraduate Aeronautical engineering and BTech Aero programs, with a particular focus on the Fundamentals of Flight, Structures, Controls, and Aerodynamics courses.  The course places a heavy emphasis on group work, open-ended design, and oral communication skills.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c93fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The individual presentation is designed to do two things: to give you a chance to get feedback on your design work prior to the design review from both the teaching staff and fellow students, and to assess your oral presentation skills.  Each student will be responsible for presenting one of the four blocks of design work to the course and 50% of the mark will be based on presentation skills.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"383fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"cd3fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f83fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"243fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Poster Session","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Each group will design and present a "poster" at a special industry day towards the end of the semester, which will invite external stakeholders from industry, defence, and academia to see what the students have developed and ask questions about their work.  These external guests will assess the posters and the answers to the questions. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"383fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"cd3fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f83fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6c3fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Industry Inspired Design Reviews","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This type of assessment is that they mimics the kinds of things
you will do in your careers after University. You are never asked in the real world to
demonstrate knowledge in a short time frame without access to outside materials like
you are on a test. In the real world, you will have meetings with engineering managers
and customers, and it’s your job to convince them of the validity and applicability of
your work. In order to do this, you need to do the following things (in order)
1. Anticipate the questions and problems that you will need to address or that might
be asked about your work
2. Analyse the problems you identify rigorously, with justification for the methods
that you use and a basis to claim that they are accurate
3. Prepare supporting materials to back up your claims and persuade your manager
/ client of your solutions

You will get detailed written feedback after the design review as well as in person feedback during the review and after in tutorial sessions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"383fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"cd3fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f83fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a03fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Milestones","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":"

Each group will be required to provide evidence of continuous action on their design project by meeting prescribed milestones in the tutorial sessions.  These milestones are assessed either satisfactory or unsatisfactory, and design teams must obtain 60% satisfactory completion to pass this assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"383fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f83fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b43fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Design Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

As part of your design project, each student will write an 8 page written report on one of the four aspects of the aircraft design process.  These reports will be scaffolded by formative feedback on a rough draft, and are designed as a way for you to document your design process but, very importantly, practice your TECHNICAL WRITING SKILLS in preparation for your thesis project

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"383fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"cd3fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f83fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e83fd9b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZEIT4502.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,aerodynamics,aeronautics,flight vehicle structures,airframe structure design
contentlets.description:
Students in Aircraft and Systems Design 2 will continue the preliminary design that they began in the first semester of the class with a greater focus on detailed design and testing. The course is divided into four parts, similar to ASD1. The course first develops much more detailed estimates of the design lift, drag, and weight and balance distributions.  Second, a propulsion system design is undertaken and performance of the aircraft estimated.  Third, simulated flight testing is conducted to evaluate the aircraft’s dynamic stability characteristics. Finally, the methods of wind tunnel testing will be used to measure drag and compare with predictions.  Concurrently with these activities, students will be conducting an individual open-ended design project related to their aircraft design.

This course is a 6 UOC capstone course and relies on the entire scope of knowledge gained in the undergraduate Aeronautical engineering and BTech Aero programs, with a particular focus on the Fundamentals of Flight, Structures, Controls, and Aerodynamics courses.  The course places a heavy emphasis on group work, open-ended design, and oral communication skills.
contentlets.title: Aircraft and Systems Design 2

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,thermodynamics and propulsion
contentlets.description: Thermodynamic analysis is used to examine a range of power cycles including internal combustion engines and gas turbines. Different levels of analysis will be used including air-standard and cold-air-standard. The thermodynamics of gaseous combustion processes will be explored. The majority of the course will apply these analysis techniques to the gas turbine cycle, and its range of applications including aircraft and marine propulsion and power generation.
contentlets.title: Applied Thermodynamics and Propulsion

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4505 - Mechanical and Aeronautical Engineering Management","description":"

This course covers engineering management activities and the engineer's professional responsibilities, during development, acquisition and sustainment of aeronautical and mechanical hardware systems. The engineer's role in a project team, scope development, task and schedule management, resource planning, procurement and financial management are explored through practical exposure to developing work breakdown structures, sequencing of tasks, scheduling resources and quality and risk management. Sustaining hardware in service is addressed through use of technical integrity based maintenance management techniques including maintenance strategies, repair or replacement decision making, condition monitoring and technical management information systems. Learning areas are reinforced by participation in a product life cycle team project and analysis of in-service maintenance case studies.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,mechanical and aeronautical engineering management
contentlets.description: This course covers engineering management activities and the engineer's professional responsibilities, during development, acquisition and sustainment of aeronautical and mechanical hardware systems. The engineer's role in a project team, scope development, task and schedule management, resource planning, procurement and financial management are explored through practical exposure to developing work breakdown structures, sequencing of tasks, scheduling resources and quality and risk management. Sustaining hardware in service is addressed through use of technical integrity based maintenance management techniques including maintenance strategies, repair or replacement decision making, condition monitoring and technical management information systems. Learning areas are reinforced by participation in a product life cycle team project and analysis of in-service maintenance case studies.

This course will introduce students to the challenges posed by orbital debris and the importance and elements of maintaining space situational awareness. Students will be exposed to a broad range of topics regarding the sources and distribution of orbital debris, the risks posed to operational spacecraft, and strategies to mitigate against these risks to ensure the sustainability of future space operations.

Scrutiny of the Bachelor of Civil Engineering (Hons) reveals that it is currently highly focused on engineering science and technical courses with limited integration of topics in comparison with real world practice. Engineers today must constantly deal with regulatory uncertainty, data limitations, and evolving methodologies, as well as a range of conflicting demands and opinions from clients, governments, public authorities and the community. Consequently, they need to understand (and be able to apply) sound engineering principles to the projects they undertake.

These principles involve technical competence, ethical practice, appropriate management, professionalism, courtesy, safety awareness and thoroughness of task execution. Relevant skills include (but are not limited to) problem solving expertise, proficiency in liaison and negotiation (with both professional bodies and individuals), research and report preparation competence, and good communication ability. In addition, engineers must be able to cope with continual technological and organisational change in the workplace and the commercial realities of industry practice. They should also be generally aware of the legal and environmental consequences of their professional actions, and exhibit a commitment to ongoing learning and contributions to their organization, profession, and the community.

In order therefore to facilitate the transition of the final year students and prepare them for the tasks they will likely face once they join their respective services, the course aims to enhance the process of learning through authentic problem solving. Students pursuing this course will be required to work in teams and to attend seminars and possible occasional field visits external to timetabled course sessions, during both semesters. These may include both professional meetings and leadership seminars.

Scheduled session contact is 5 hours per week, during which students can meet with supervisors. Extra consulation can be arranged with supervisors at agreed time and in various forms. Each students is anticipated to work 7 additional hours on average each week on the project.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,civil engineering practice,engineering principles
contentlets.description:
Scrutiny of the Bachelor of Civil Engineering (Hons) reveals that it is currently highly focused on engineering science and technical courses with limited integration of topics in comparison with real world practice. Engineers today must constantly deal with regulatory uncertainty, data limitations, and evolving methodologies, as well as a range of conflicting demands and opinions from clients, governments, public authorities and the community. Consequently, they need to understand (and be able to apply) sound engineering principles to the projects they undertake.

These principles involve technical competence, ethical practice, appropriate management, professionalism, courtesy, safety awareness and thoroughness of task execution. Relevant skills include (but are not limited to) problem solving expertise, proficiency in liaison and negotiation (with both professional bodies and individuals), research and report preparation competence, and good communication ability. In addition, engineers must be able to cope with continual technological and organisational change in the workplace and the commercial realities of industry practice. They should also be generally aware of the legal and environmental consequences of their professional actions, and exhibit a commitment to ongoing learning and contributions to their organization, profession, and the community.

In order therefore to facilitate the transition of the final year students and prepare them for the tasks they will likely face once they join their respective services, the course aims to enhance the process of learning through authentic problem solving. Students pursuing this course will be required to work in teams and to attend seminars and possible occasional field visits external to timetabled course sessions, during both semesters. These may include both professional meetings and leadership seminars.

Scheduled session contact is 4 hours per week, during which students can meet with supervisors. Extra consulation can be arranged with supervisors at agreed time and in various forms. Each students is anticipated to work 8 additional hours on average each week on the project.
contentlets.title: Civil Design Practice Extension

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4603","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4603 - Finite Element Method","description":"

These days the analysis of all but the simple structures is carried out with the aid of computer programs based on the finite element method (FE). The user of the FE method has to decide what kind of elements should be used, and how many of them? Where should the mesh be fine and where may it be coarse? Can the model be simplified? How accurate will the answers be, and how can they be checked? One need not understand all the mathematics of the finite element to answer these questions. However a competent user must have an understanding of the preliminary mathematics and must be able to understand how elements behave in order to choose suitable kinds, sizes and shapes of elements, and to guard against misinterpretations and unrealistically high expectations. This course is a balanced theoretical and practical introduction to the use of the FE method. The first part deals with mathematical preliminaries such as the weighted residual methods, finite element approximation and numerical integration. The second part is an application of the finite element method to linear plane elasticity problems. The third part deals with heat transfer.  All the lectures include computational work in which problems are to be solved using Matlab and ABAQUS.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4604","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4604 - Hydrology and Environmental Engineering Practice","description":"

This final-year undergraduate course exposes students to the principles and engineering practice of hydrology and environmental engineering. This includes the analysis of hydrological processes in surface and groundwater, precipitation, runoff, evapotranspiration, infiltration, recharge and discharge, catchment hydrology and water resources management. This course also examines the practice of environmental engineering of interest to civil engineering industry and Defence, including contamination site investigations and remediation, water and wastewater treatment, air pollution management, environmental management and environmental impact assessment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a5fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961978","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Excursion","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

An excursion will be conducted in this course, in relation to the environmental engineering component. This will involve visits to major water and wastewater treatment facilities in the ACT. The excursion will involve an assignment, which will consist of 5% of the marks. Attendance on the excursion will be compulsory.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"11fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6dfdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d1fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"05fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The examination components of the assessment provide assurance that the knowledge and understanding demonstrated are your own and a measure of that knowledge and understanding. They also provide an extra incentive for study.  

The mid-session quiz will consider the first 5-6 weeks topics of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"11fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6dfdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d1fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"05fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

The examination components of the assessment provide assurance that the knowledge and understanding demonstrated are your own and a measure of that knowledge and understanding. They also provide an extra incentive for study. 

The final examination will be 3 hours long, and make up 45% of the marks. It will be held either in the final week of session or the final exam period. Detailed instructions for the final exam will be issued with the examination timetable.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"11fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6dfdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"a9fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d1fdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4dfdd5ffdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Twomajor assignments, respectively on environmental engineering practice and hydrological practice, will form an important component of the assessment for this course. In Assignment 1, each student will choose and examine a case study, based on a potentially contaminated site.  This will be used to develop several themes of environmental engineering practice, as examined in this course. In Assignment 2, each student will progressively develop an analysis of a rural catchment reflecting the learning outcomes of the course.  The work will include the development of a stormwater design for a small residential development planning to be constructed within the catchment.

The assignments will be offered in case study mode, to foster the development of the students’ skills in engineering practice.  This will include referencing of standards and original source materials, the development of technical analyses, and the reporting of the proposed solutions. The detailed technical work on each project and the preparation of the assignment submission itself must be your own work. 

The written component of the assignments should be submitted on Moodle, using the standard coversheet. Please submit each assignment in pdf format only (not Word format), in a single document, with all fonts embedded (otherwise it will be corrupted and unreadable). Please do not make multiple document submissions for a single assignment. All supporting information (e.g. spreadsheet, Matlab, Maple or other files) must also be attached in their own files. All assignment submissions must also start with the SEIT coversheet, available on Moodle.

This course fits in the program design stream for mechanical engineering. It follows on from ZEIT1501 Engineering Practice and Design, ZEIT2501 Mechanical and Electronic Design and ZEIT 3700 Mechanical Design-1.



It is assumed that you have successfully completed all core courses to the end of Third Year in the program 4474 Mechanical Engineering: if you have not done so, you should consult with the lecturer before commencing this course.



Mechanical design uses appropriate techniques to apply knowledge so that machines and systems can be constructed to satisfy requirements. Although the requirements are the yardstick for successful design, the design engineer is often presented with ones which are inadequate to specify the design completely and must negotiate expanded requirements to do so. It is the objective of this course to engage the participants in all aspects of the design process on a well-defined “machine”. The course also introduces principles of design optimization that is increasingly becoming an integral part of the design process.



This 6-unit course is divided into two parts: Design Optimization (50%) and Mechanical Design Project (50%). Lectures and Studio sessions will be used throughout the session to cover the above two aspects.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cbfe91b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design project 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Individual projects to assess student's understanding of design process. Individual and collective feedback will be provided via Moodle/ in class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"36fe91b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3afe91b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"26fe91b3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961953","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design Project 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

The project will involve designing and prototyping of a solution to a given problem. The project will be undertaken in teams, with assessment covering both the team performance and invididual contribution. Continous feedback will be provided during the studio sessions with a summative mark at the end.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology,engineering analysis,mechanical design,design optimization
contentlets.description:
This course fits in the program design stream for mechanical engineering. It follows on from ZEIT1501 Engineering Practice and Design, ZEIT2501 Mechanical and Electronic Design and ZEIT 3700 Mechanical Design-1.


It is assumed that you have successfully completed all core courses to the end of Third Year in the program 4474 Mechanical Engineering: if you have not done so, you should consult with the lecturer before commencing this course.


Mechanical design uses appropriate techniques to apply knowledge so that machines and systems can be constructed to satisfy requirements. Although the requirements are the yardstick for successful design, the design engineer is often presented with ones which are inadequate to specify the design completely and must negotiate expanded requirements to do so. It is the objective of this course to engage the participants in all aspects of the design process on a well-defined “machine”. The course also introduces principles of design optimization that is increasingly becoming an integral part of the design process.


This 6-unit course is divided into two parts: Design Optimization (50%) and Mechanical Design Project (50%). Lectures and Studio sessions will be used throughout the session to cover the above two aspects.
contentlets.title: Mechanical Design 2

This is a technically detailed 6 Unit of Credit course on instrumentation systems for engineering measurement, specifically designed for mechanical engineers, and assumes only limited exposure to electronic engineering and computing topics.  It is available as an elective for interested students in other BE and BTech(Aero) degree programs.  While no experience of microcontrollers is assumed, students will be required to quickly learn how to perform number base conversions and to develop basic computer programs for microcontroller-based measurements as part of the course.


While this course is required to complete the marine stream of the EE degree program, electrical engineering students will only be able to enrol with the permission of the EE program co-ordinator, as there are alternative courses covering similar material that are better integrated with the other EE program courses.


Measurement is essential in most branches of engineering, and will generally require the use of instrumentation assembled into a measurement system.  In recent times, such measurement systems are predominantly associated with microcontrollers.  Applications extend from simple checks on dimensions, temperature and similar quantities to monitoring rapidly varying quantities whose magnitudes and variations are required for closed loop control of complex machines.

Written tutorial problems to show facility with instrumentation hand-calculations.  Feedback in the form of a solution and marks on the submitted work,

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9b3e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d73e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0b3e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"6 laboratories and prac test","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

6 laboratories are attempted.  Reports are compulsory for the first lab, and students can choose another two of the remaining five for formal assessments.The marks for the reports that are not assessed are formative.  There is a summative in-class test where students must perform a measurement task based upon those tasks that were completed in the laboratory component of the course.  Material based on any of the 6 labs may be chosen for the test.  Feedback is provided through comments on the completed lab test sheet.  The average of the three assessed labs will form 20% of the total course assessment and the prac test will make up a further 10% of the total assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"173e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9b3e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"433e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Measurement Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a group project requiring students to design and construct a pre-determined simple instrumentation system.  Each student is required to perform a single-student task that is marked as an individual as well as receiving marks as a group for the overall project design.  Feedback is provided in the form of comments on the final report.  This assessment is worth 30% of the total assessment mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"173e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9b3e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9b3e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d73e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b3e9133db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

A 20 minute verbal examination covering the students' understanding of the material in the course.  Students are provided with guidance on how their performance was and how it could be improved after the test, and are also asked to self-assess.  This is worth 30% of the total assessment.

This course provides an introduction to the principles of military land mobility and the impact of weapons on these platforms. Students will be exposed to a range of issues including general design requirements, terra-mechanics, mobility, counter mobility, reliability, vulnerability and survivability. The course will be delivered through a combination of lectures and tutorials.

This course provides an introduction to the principles of marine engineering and propulsion to enable students studying the Bachelor of Engineering (Mechanical) and Bachelor of Engineering (Electrical) to complete a marine specialisation which aligns to Marine Engineer Officer competencies. Key topics include ship propulsion and auxiliary ship systems and equipment. This course will be delivered through a combination of lectures, tutorials and design studio activities.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZEIT4901","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZEIT4901 - Engineering Research 4A","description":"

Students will undertake a problem-based learning project of scope commensurate with the level of attainment expected of a final-year Electrical Engineering student in the CDF Students Program. The project will take the form of a piece of research or investigation, or a feasibility study or design chosen from a list of topics selected or approved by the Head of School. In each case at least one staff member will be nominated as a supervisor to provide guidance and general supervision during the project. Students will be assessed through their seminar presentations, attended by other students and members of staff, and the project thesis. Evidence of sufficient progress may be required from time to time. The thesis, which will have a nominal length of 20,000 words, is to be presented both typed and suitably bound and in electronic form.


During the year students will be required to participate in a series of specialist lectures and seminars. Specialist lectures will normally take the form of attendance by students on at least 8 occasions during the year at nominated meetings of the local professional societies.


This is the first half of a year-long course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7ef29e27db399850eb6b147a3a96191c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Research Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

A 10 page Research Summary is a written reflection on the project definition, impact, significance, and conclusions will be submitted for review to the School Undergraduate Journal. It is a communication of your contribution to the focus area and engineering discipline.

It will be submitted electronically in PDF format to the School student journal (JUER) (see https://gateway.unsw.adfa.edu.au/ojs/index.php/ju er/index).

Guidelines on document structure are provided. Your supervisor and Panel will also provide guidance on how to write and structure this document to best communicate the significance of your project work to the area of research.

All research summary reports must go through the Turnitin check via the course Moodle site. All students must submit their draft versions two weeks before the project seminar week for a prelim screening so that they can use the Originality Report generated to improve their final version. The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"26f29e27db399850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2af25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"66f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"72f29e27db399850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aaf25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aef25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eaf25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ef25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619ac","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Preliminary Report and Viva","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The student will, in consultation with the supervisor/s develop a Preliminary/Interim Report that outlines the scope and significance of the intended research. It will define where this project sits in the wider context of its application, and will include a project management timeline. It will detail reading and progress made on the project up till the date of submission. This will serve as a document to address in the oral defence. It should be submitted by email to the supervisor and the Panel Chair.

An oral defence or Viva to a small panel of academics of your project direction, and partial work towards the objectives will be scheduled in Weeks 11 and 12 of your first project semester for ZEIT4901. The submitted Preliminary Report above, will serve as supporting documentation in this defence. The members of the panel will assign a mark. The format of the Viva will be communicated to you and the Panel.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2af25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"66f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"a2f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aaf25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aef25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eaf25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d2f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a961997","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

A Seminar of 12 minutes duration with 3 minutes of question time will be conducted in Week 11 and 12 of your second project semester the week. The audience of this seminar will be your supervisors, peers, academic and technical staff, and members of the general public. The academic members of the audience will assess this work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2af25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"66f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"a2f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aaf25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aef25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eaf25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d2f25e27db399850eb6b147a3a9619a8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Specific Deliverable","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

A Project Specific Deliverable will be identified by your supervisor as reasonable documentation required to support and document the project work so it may be continued by others. This may include electronic working files and designs, documentation of the operations of tools and software used in the project, a traditional research thesis, etc.

The form of this deliverable will be detailed in writing at the outset of your study and the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed, and will have been recognised by the Panel as representing a similar workload as required of other students enrolled in this course.

The Project Specific Deliverable should be provided directly to the supervisor by Monday, revision week of the second project semester, and the quality and content will form part of their assessment of your work.

The due date for the final version summary and the corresponding Originality Report is the Monday of Week 13 of the second project semester. The Panel will assess and review this work, and may request revisions, whereupon the final submission completes this assessment.

A Project Specific Deliverable will be identified by your supervisor as reasonable documentation required to support and document the project work so it may be continued by others. This may include electronic working files and designs, documentation of the operations of tools and software used in the project, a traditional research thesis, etc.

The form of this deliverable will be detailed in writing at the outset of your study and the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) signed, and will have been recognised by the Panel as representing a similar workload as required of other students enrolled in this course.

The Project Specific Deliverable should be provided directly to the supervisor by Monday, revision week of the second project semester, and the quality and content will form part of their assessment of your work.

contentlets.keywords: engineering and information technology
contentlets.description:
Students will undertake a problem-based learning project of scope commensurate with the level of attainment expected of a final-year Engineering student in the CDF Students Program. The project will take the form of a piece of research or investigation, or a feasibility study or design chosen from a list of topics selected or approved by the Head of School. In each case at least one staff member will be nominated as a supervisor to provide guidance and general supervision during the project. Students will be assessed through their seminar presentations, attended by other students and members of staff, and the project thesis. Evidence of sufficient progress may be required from time to time. The thesis, which will have a nominal length of 20,000 words, is to be presented not later than the first day of the examination period. Theses must be presented both typed and suitably bound and in electronic form.

This is the second half of a year-long course.
contentlets.title: Engineering Research 4B
